editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Dissuade me not.

sp.speaker: Clere.
sp.l: It will breed a brawl.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I care not, I wear a sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And wear discretion with it,
Or cast it off, let that direct your arm,
'Tis madness else, not valour, and more base
Than to receive a wrong.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why would you have me
Sit down with a disgrace, and thank the doer?
We are not Stoics, and that passive courage
Is only now, commendable in lackeys,
Peasants, and tradesmen, not in men of rank,
And quality, as I am.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Do not cherish
That daring vice, for which the whole age suffers
The blood of our bold youth, that heretofore
Was spent in honourable action,
Or to defend, or to enlarge the kingdom,
For the honour of our country, and our prince,
Pours itself out, with prodigal expense
Upon our mother's lap, the earth that bred us
For every trifle, and these private duels,
Which had their first original from the French;
(And for which, to this day, we are justly censured)
And banished from all civil governments
Scarce three in Venice, in as many years;
In Florence, they are rarer, and in all
The fair dominions of the Spanish King,
They are never heard of: nay, those neighbour countries,,
Which gladly imitate our other follies,
And come at a dear rate to buy them of us,
Begin now to detest them.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you? and yet —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And I have heard, that some of our late Kings,
For the lie, wearing of a mistress, feathers;
A cheat at cards or dice and such like causes,
Have lost as many gallant gentlemen,
As might have met the great Turk in the field
With confidence of a glorious victory,
And shall we then —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No more, for shame no more,
Are you become a patron to? 'tis a new one,
No more on't, burn't, give it to some orator,
To help him to enlarge his exercise,
With such a one, it might do well, and profit
The curate of the parish, but for Cleremont
The bold, and undertaking Cleremont,
To talk thus to his friend his friend that knows him,
Dinant, that knows his Cleremont, is absurd,
And mere apocrypha.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why, what know you of me?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why if thou hast forgotten thyself, I'll tell thee,
And not look back, to speak of what thou wert
At fifteen, for at those years, I have heard
Thou wast fleshed, and entered bravely.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Well sir, well.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But yesterday, thou wast the common second,
Of all that only knew thee, thou hadst bills
Set up on every post, to give thee notice,
Where any difference was, and who were parties,
And as, to save the charges of the law;
Poor men seek arbitrators, thou wert chosen
By such as knew thee not, to compound quarrels:
But thou wert so delighted with the sport,
That if there were no just cause, thou wouldst make one,
Or be engaged thyself: this godly calling
Thou hast followed five and twenty years, and studied
The criticisms of contentions, and art thou
In so few hours transformed? certain this night
Thou hast had strange dreams, or rather visions.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yes, sir,
I have seen fools, and fighters, chained together,
And the fighters had the upper hand and whipped first,
The poor sots laughing at 'em. What I have been
It skills not, what I will be is resolved on.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why then you'll fight no more?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Such is my purpose.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: On no occasion?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: There you stagger me,
Some kind of wrongs there are, which flesh and blood
Cannot endure.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not willingly,
Live a protested coward, or be called one?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Words, are but words.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nor wouldst thou take a blow?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not from my friend, though drunk, and from an enemy,
I think much less.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: There's some hope of thee left then.
Wouldst thou hear me, behind my back disgraced?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Do you think I am a rogue? they that should do it
Had better been born dumb.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Or in thy presence?
See me o'ercharged with odds?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'd fall myself first.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Wouldst thou endure thy mistress be taken from thee,
And thou sit quiet?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: There you touch my honour,
No French man can endure that.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl — upon thee,
Why dost thou talk of peace then? that dar'st suffer
Nothing, or in thyself, or in thy friend
That is unmanly?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That I grant, I cannot:
But I'll not quarrel with this gentleman,
For wearing stammel breeches, or this gamester,
For playing a thousand pounds, that owes me nothing;
For this man's taking up a common wench
In rags, and lousy, then maintaining her
Caroched in cloth of tissue, nor five hundred
Of such like toys, that at no part concern me;
Marry, where my honour, or my friend is questioned,
I have a sword, and I think I may use it
To the cutting of a rascal's throat, or so,
Like a good christian.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou art of a fine religion,
And rather then we'll make a schism in friendship,
I will be of it: but to be serious,
Thou art acquainted with my tedious love-suit
To fair Lamira.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Too well sir, and remember
Your presents, courtship, that's too good a name,
Your slave-like services, your morning music;
Your walking three hours in the rain at midnight,
To see her at her window, sometimes laughed at,
Sometimes admitted, and vouchsafed to kiss
Her glove, her skirt, nay I have heard, her slippers,
How then you triumphed?
Here was love forsooth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: These follies I deny not,
Such a contemptible thing, my dotage made me,
But my reward for this —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As you deserved.
For he that makes a goddess of a puppet,
Merits no other recompense.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This day friend,
For thou art so —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am no flatterer.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This proud, ingrateful she, is married to
Lame Champernell.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know him, he has been
As tall a seaman, and has thrived as well by't,
The loss of a leg and an arm deducted, as any
That ever put from Marseils: you are tame,
Pl — on't, it mads me; if it were my case,
I should kill all the family.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yet but now
You did preach patience.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I then came from confession,
And 't was enjoined me three hours for a penance,
To be a peaceable man, and to talk like one,
But now, all else being pardoned, I begin
On a new tally, foot do any thing,
I'll second you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I would not willingly
Make red, my yet white conscience, yet I purpose
In the open street, as they come from the temple,
(For this way they must pass,) to speak my wrongs,
And do it boldly. Music plays.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Were thy tongue a cannon,
I would stand by thee, boy, they come, upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Observe a little first.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is fine fiddling.

div.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell Lamira, nurse, Beaupre Verdoone.

body.head: An epithalamin song at the wedding.

lg.l: Come away bring on the bride
And place her by her lover's side:
You fair troop of maids attend her,
Pure and holy thoughts be friend her.
Blush, and wish, you virgins all
Many such fair nights may fall
Hymen, fill the house with joy,
Bless the bed, with holy love,
Now fair or be of beauty move.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Stand by, for 'twill be heard.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: This is strange rudeness.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis courtship, balanced with injuries,
You all look pale with guilt, but I will die
Your cheeks with blushes, if in your seared veins,
There yet remain so much of honest blood
To make the colour; first to ye my lord,
The father of this bride, whom you have sent
Alive into her grave.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: How? to her grave?

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: Be patient sir, I'll speak of you anon,
You that allowed me liberal access,
To make my way with service, and approved of
My birth, my person, years, and no base fortune:
You that are rich, and but in this held wise too,
That as a father should have looked upon
Your daughter in a husband, and aimed more
At what her youth, and heat of blood required
In lawful pleasures, than the parting from
Your crowns to pay her dowry: you that already
Have one foot in the grave, yet study profit,
As if you were assured, to live here ever;
What poor end had you, in this choice? in what
Deserve I your contempt? my house, and honours,
At all parts equal yours, my fame as fair,
And not to praise myself, the city ranks me,
In the first file, of her most hopeful gentry:
But Champernell is rich, and needs a nurse,
And not your gold: and add to that, he's old too,
His whole estate in likelihood, to descend
Upon a family; here was providence,
I grant, but in a nobleman, base thrift:
No merchants, nay, no pirates, sell for bondmen.
Their countrymen, but you, a gentleman,
To save a little gold have sold your daughter
To worse than slavery.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This was spoke home indeed.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.l: Sir, I shall take some other time to tell you,
That this harsh language, was delivered to
An old man, but my father.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Proceed in your design, let me alone,
To answer him, or any man.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You presume
Too much upon your name, but may be cousined.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for you, most unmindful of my service,
For now I may upbraid you, and with honour,
Since all is lost, and yet I am a gainer,
In being delivered from a torment in you,
For such you must have been, you to whom nature
Gave with a liberal hand, most excellent form,
Your education, language, and discourse,
And judgement to distinguish when you shall
With feeling sorrow, understand how wretched
And miserable, you have made yourself,
And but yourself, have nothing to accuse,
Can you with hope from any beg compassion?
But you will say, you served your father's pleasure,
Forgetting that unjust commands of parents
Are not to be obeyed, or that you are rich,
And that to wealth, all pleasure else are servants,
Yet but consider, how this wealth was purchased,
'Twill trouble the possession.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You sir know
I got it, and with honour.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But from whom?
Remember that, and how: you'll come indeed
To houses bravely furnished, but demanding
Where it was bought, this soldier will not lie,
But answer truly, this rich cloth of arras,
I made my prize in such a ship, this plate
Was my share in another; these fair jewels,
Coming ashore, I got in such a village,
The maid, or matron killed, from whom they were ravished,
The wines you drink, are guilty too, for this,
This Candy wine, three merchants were undone,
These suckets break as many more, in brief,
All you shall wear, or touch, or see, is purchased
By lawless force, and you but revel in
The tears, and groans, of such as were the owners.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: 'Tis false, most basely false.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Let losers' talk.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lastly, those joys, those best of joys, which Hymen
Freely bestows on such, that come to tie
The sacred knot he blesses, won unto it
By equal love, and mutual affection,
Not blindly led, with the desire of riches,
Most miserable you, shall never taste of,
This marriage night, you'll meet a widow's bed,
Or failing of those pleasures, all brides look for,
Sin in your wish it were so,

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Thou art a villain,
A base, malicious slanderer.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Strike him.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No, he is not worth a blow.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O that I had thee
In some close vault that only would yield room
To me to use my sword, to thee no hope
To run away, I would make thee on thy knees,
Bite out the tongue that wronged me.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Pray you have patience.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: This day I am to be your sovereign,
Let me command you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: I am lost with rage,
And know not what I am myself, nor you:
Away, dare such as you, that love the smoke
Of peace, more than the fire of glorious war,
And like unprofitable drones, feed on
Your grandsires labours, that, as I am now,
Were gathering bees, and filled their hive, this country
With brave triumphant spoils, censure our actions?
You object my prizes to me, had you seen
The horror of a sea-fight, with what danger
I made them mine; the fire I fearless fought in
And quenched it in mine enemy's blood, which straight
Like oil poured out on't, made it burn anew;
My deck blown up, with noise enough to mock
The loudest thunder, and the desperate fools
That boarded me, sent to defy the tempest
That were against me to the angry sea,
Frighted with men thrown o'er; no victory,
But in despite of the four elements,
The fire, the air, the sea, and sands hid in it
To be achieved, you would confess poor men,
(Though hopeless, such an honourable way
To get or wealth, or honour) in yourselves;
He that through all these dreadful passages,
Pursued and overtook them, unaffrighted,
Deserves reward, and not to have it styled
By the base name of theft.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is the courtship,
That you must look for, madam.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Twill do well,
When nothing can be done, to spend the night with:
Your tongue is sound, good lord, I could wish
For this young lady's sake this leg, this arm,
And there is something else I will not name,
(Though 'tis the only thing that must content her)
Had the same vigour.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You shall buy these scoffs
With your best blood, help me once noble anger,
(Nay stir not, I alone must right myself)
And with one leg transport me to correct
These scandalous praters: o that noble woundsFalls.
Should hinder just revenge? D'ye jeer me too?
I got these not as you do your diseases
In brothels, or with riotous abuse
Of wine in taverns; I have one leg shot,
One arm disabled, and am honoured more,
By losing them as I did in the face
Of a brave enemy then if they were
As when I put to sea; you are French men only,
In that you have been laid, and cured, go to:
You mock my leg but every bone about you,
Makes you good almanac-makers, to foretell
What weather we shall have.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Put up your sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Or turn it to a crutch, there't may be useful,
And live, on the relation to your wife,
Of what a brave man you were once.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And tell her
What a fine virtue, 'tis in a young lady
To give an old man pap.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Or hire a surgeon
To teach her to roll up your broken limbs.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To make a poultice, and endure the scent
Of oils and nasty plasters.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Fie sir, fie,
You that have stood all dangers of all kinds,
To yield to a rival's scoff?

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Shed tears upon
Your wedding day? this is unmanly gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: They are tears of anger oh that I should live
To play the woman thus? All powerful heaven,
Restore me, but one hour, that strength again,
That I had once, to chastise in these men,
Their follies, and ill manners, and that done,
When you please, I'll yield up the fort of life,
And do it gladly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We ha' the better of him,
We ha' made him cry.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: You shall have satisfaction,
And I will do it nobly, or disclaim me.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I say no more you have a brother, sister,
This is your wedding day, we are in the street,
And howsoever, they forget their honour,
'Tis fit I lose not mine, by their example.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: If there be laws in Paris look to answer
This insolent affront

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You that live by them,
Study 'em for heaven's sake; for my part I know not
Nor care not what they are, is their ought else
That you would say?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nothing, I have my ends,
Lamira weeps, I have said too much I fear;
So dear once I loved her, that I cannot
Endure to see her tears. Exiunt. Dionant and Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: See you perform it,
And do it like my nephew.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: If I fail in't
Ne'er know me more, cousin Beaupre

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Repent not
What thou hast done, my life, thou shalt not find
I am decrepit; in my love, and service,
I will be young, and constant, and believe me,
For thou shall find it true, in scorn of all
The scandals these rude men have thrown upon me
I'll meet thy pleasures, with a young man's ardour
And in all circumstances, of a husband,
Perform my parts.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Good sir, I am your servant,
And 'tis too late now, if I did repent,
(Which as I am a virgin yet, I do not)
To undo the knot, that by the church is tied
Only I would beseech ye, as you have,
A good opinion of me, and my virtues,
For so you have pleased to style my innocent weakness,
That what hath passed between dinant and me,
Or what now in your hearing he hath spoken,
Beget not doubts, or fears.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: I apprehend you,
You think I will be jealous, as I live
Thou art mistaken sweet; and to confirm it
Discourse with whom thou wilt, ride where thou wilt,
Feast whom thou wilt, as often as thou wilt,
For I will have no other guards upon thee
Then thine own thoughts,

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: I'll use this liberty
With moderation sir,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I am resolved
Steal off, I'll follow you,

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Come sir, you droop,
Till you find cause, which I shall never give
Dislike not of your son in law,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Sir, you teach me
The language I should use; I am most happy
In being so near you. Exeunt Verdone and Beaupre.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: O my fears good nurse
Follow my brother unobserved and learn,
Which way he takes.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I will be careful madam. Exit nurse.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Between us compliments are superfluous,
One gentlemen, th' affront we have met here
We'll think upon hereafter, 'twere unfit
To cherish any thought to breed unrest,
Or to ourselves, or to our nuptial feast.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We shall have sport, ne'er fear't

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What sport I prithee?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why we must fight, I know it, and I long for't
It was apparent in the fiery eye,
Of young Verdoone, Beaupre looked pale and shook too,
Familiar signs of anger. They are both brave fellows
Tried and approved, and I am proved to encounter.
With men, from whom no honour can be lost
They will play up to a man, and set him off,
When ere I go to the field, heaven keep me from
The meeting of an unfleshed youth or coward,
The first to get a name, comes on too hot,
The coward is so swift in giving ground,
There is no overtaking him, without
A hunting nag, well breathed too.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: All this while,
You ne'er think on the danger,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why 'tis no more,
Then meeting of a dozen friends at supper,
And drinking hard; mischief comes there unlooked for,
I am sure as sudden, and strikes home as often,
For this we are prepared

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lamira loves
Her brother Beaupre dear.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What of that?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And should he call me to account for what
But now I speak, nor can I with mine honour
Recant my words, that little hope is left me,
'Ere to enjoy what (Next to heaven I long for,)
Is taken from me,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why what can you hope for,
She being now married?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: On my Cleremont,
To you all secrets of my heart lie open,
And I rest most secure that whatsoever
I look up there, is as a private thought,
And will no farther wrong me, I am a Frenchman,
And for the greater part, we are born courtiers,
She is a woman, and however yet,
No heat of service, had the power to melt
Her frozen chastity, time and opportunity
May work her to my ends, I confess ill ones,
And yet I must pursue 'em: now her marriage,
In probability, will no way hurt,
But rather help me,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Sits the wind there? pray you tell me
How far off, dwells your love from lust?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Too near,
But prithee chide me not,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not I, go on boy,
I have faults myself, and will not reprehend
A crime I am not free from: for her marriage,
I do esteem it (And most bachelors are
Of my opinion) as a fair protection,
To play the wanton, without loss of honour.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Would she make rise of't so, I were most happy.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No more of this, judge now,
Whither I have the gift of prophecy.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Monsieur dinant.
I am glad to find you, sir.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I am at your service.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Good monsieur Cleremont, I have long wished
To be known better to you,

sp.speaker: Cl●r.
sp.l: My desires
Embrace your wishes sir,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Sir, I have ever
Esteemed you truly noble, and profess.
I should have been most proud, to have had the honour,
To call you brother, but my father's pleasure
Denied that happiness, I know no man lives,
That can command his passions, and therefore
Dare not condemn, the late intemperate language
You were pleased to use, to my father and my sister
He's old and she a woman, i most forty,
My honour does compel me to entreat you,
To do me the favour, with your sword to meet me
A mile without the city.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You much honour me.
In the demand, I'll gladly wait upon you,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: O sir you teach me what to say: the time?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: With the next sun, if you think fit.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: The place.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Near to the vineyard eastward from the city,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I like it well, this gentleman if you please
Will keep me company,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That is agreed on;
And in my friend's behalf I will attend him

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You shall not miss my service.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Good day gentlemen. Ex. Beaup. and Virdoone.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At your commandment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Proved to be your servants,
I think there is no nation under heaven
That cut their enemies' throats with compliment,
And such fine tricks as we do: if you have
Any few prayers to say, this night you may
Call 'em to mind and use 'em, for myself,
As I have little to lose, my care is less,
So till tomorrow morning, I bequeath you,
To your devotions; and those paid, but use
That noble courage I have seen, and we
Shall fight, as in a castle,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thou art all honour,
Thy resolution, would steel a coward,
And I most fortunate, in such a friend,
All tenderness, and nice respect of woman,
Be now far from me, reputation take
A full possession of my heart, and prove
Honour the first place holds, the second love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Sleeps my lord still Carlote.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Not to be waked
By your ladyship's cheerful looks, I well perceive
That this night, the good lord hath been
At an unusual service, and no wonder
If he rest after it

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: You are very bold

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Your creature madam and when you are pleased
Sadness to me's a stranger, your good pardon
If I speak like a fool, I could have wished,
To have ta'ne your place tonight , had bold dinant
Your first and most obsequious servant tasted
Those delicates, which by his lethargy
As it appears, have cloyed my lord,

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I am silenced madam

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Saw you my nurse this morning?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No madam.

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: I am full of fears. Knock within.
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: She you enquired for

sp.speaker: Lamira.
sp.l: Bring her in, and leave me. Ex. Charlote. Enter nurse.
Now nurse what news.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: O lady dreadful ones,
They are to fight this morning, there's no remedy
I saw my lord your brother, and Verdoone.
Take horse as I came by,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Where's Cleremont?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I met him too, and mounted.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Where's dinant?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: There's all the hope, I have stayed him with a trick,
If I have done well so,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: What trick?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I 'Told him,
Your ladyship laid your command upon him,
To attend you presently, and to confirm it,
Gave him the ring' he oft hath seen you wear,
That you bestowed on me; he waits without
Disguised, and if you have that power in him,
As I presume you have, it is in you
To stay or alter him.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Have you learned the place,
Where they are to encounter?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Yes 'tis where
The Duke of Burgundy, met Lewis th' eleventh

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Enough I will reward thee liberally,Ex. nurse.
Go bring him in, full dear I loved dinant,
While it was lawful, but those fires are quenched,
I being now another's, truth forgive me
And let dissimulation, be no crime,
Though most unwillingly, I put it on
To guard a brother's safety.

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: Now your pleasure,
Though ill you have deserved it, you perceived
I am still your fool, and cannot but obey
Whatever you command

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: You speak as if
You did repent it and 'tis not worth my thanks then,
But there has been a time, in which you would
Receive this as a favour

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Hope was left then
Of recompense.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Why I am still Lamira.
And you dinant and 'tis yet in my power
I dare not say, I'll put it into act,
To reward your love and service,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: There's some comfort,

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: But think not that so low I prize my fame,
To give it up to any man that refuses
To buy it, or with danger or performance
Of what I shall enjoin him,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Name that danger
Be it of what horrid shape soever lady
Which I will shrink at; only at this instant
Be speedy in't

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I'll put you to the trial:
You shall not fight today, do you start at that?
Not with my brother, I have heard your difference,
Mine is no Helen's beauty, to be purchased
With blood, and so defended if you look for
Favours from me, deserve them with obedience,
There's no way else to gain 'em

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You command
What with mine honour I cannot obey
Which lies at pawn against it and a friend
Equally dear as that, or life engaged,
Not for himself, but me.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Why, foolish man,
Dare you solicit me, to serve your lust,
In which not only, I abuse my lord,
My father, and my family, but write whore,
Though not upon my forehead, in my conscience,
To be read hourly, and yet name your honours?
Yours suffer but in circumstance; mine in substance,
If you obey me, you part with some credit,
From whom? the giddy multitude; but mankind
Will censure me, and justly

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will lose,
What most I do desire, rather than hazard
So dear a friend, or write myself a coward,
'Tis better be no man

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: This will not do;
Why I desire not, you should be a coward,
Nor do I weigh my brother's life with yours,
Meet him, fight with him, do, and kill him fairly,
Let me not suffer for you, I am careless.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Suffer for me?

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: For you, my kindness to you,
Already brands me, with a strumpet's name,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O that I knew the wretch!

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I will not name him,
Nor give you any character to know him;
But if you dare, and instantly ride forth
At the West port of the city, and defend there
My reputation, against all you meet,
For two hours on lie, I'll not swear dinant,
To satisfy, (Though sure I think I shall)
Whatever you desire, if you deny this
Be desperate, for willingly, by this light,
I'll never see thee more

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Two hours, do you say?

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: Only two hours,

sp.speaker: Dina.
sp.l: I were no gentleman,
Should I make scruple of it; this favour arms me,
And boldly ill 'Perform it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lamir.
sp.l: I am glad on't.
This will prevent their meeting yet, and keep
My brother safe, which was the mark I shot at. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Cleremont, as in the field.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am first i'th field that honours gained of our side
Pray heaven I may get of as honourably,
The hour is past, I wonder dinant comes not,
This is the place, I cannot see him yet;
It is his quarrel too, that brought me hither,
And I ne'er knew him yet, but to this honour,
A firm and worthy friend, yet I see nothing,
Nor horse nor man; 'twould vex me, to be left here,
To th' mercy of two swords, and two approved ones
I never knew him last.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: You are well met Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: You are a fair gentleman, and love your friend sir
What are you ready the time has over ta'en us?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And this you know the place.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No dinant yet?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We come not now to argue, but to do;
We wait you sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: There's no time passed yet. Gentlemen,
We have day enough: is't possible he comes not?
You see I am ready here, and do but stay,
Till my friend come, walk but a turn or two,
'Twill not be long.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: We came to fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Ye shall fight gentlemen,
And fight enough, but a short turn or two
I think I see him, set up your watch, we'll fight by it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That is not he; we will not be deluded.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Am I bobbed thus, pray take a pipe of tobacco?
Or sing but some new air; by that time, gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Come draw your sword, you know the custom here sir
First come, first served

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Though it be held a custom,
And practised so, I do not hold it honest;
What honour can you both win on me single?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Yield up you sword then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yield my sword? that's hebrew;
I'll be first cut a pieces; hold but a while,
I'll take the next that comes,
You are an old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes indeed am I, sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And wear no sword?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I need none; sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I would you did, and had one;
I want now such a foolish courtesy
You see these gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You want a second.
In good faith sir, I was never handsome at it,
I would you had my son, but he's in Italy,
A proper gentleman; you may do well gallants
If you quarrel be not capital, to have more mercy,
The gentleman may do his country —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Now I beseech you, sir,
If you dare not fight, do not stay to beg my pardon,
There lies your way.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You see your fortune,
You had better yield your sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pray ye stay a little
Upon mine honesty, you shall be fought with;
Well, dinant, well, these wear swords and seem brave fellows
As you are gentlemen, one of you supply me
I want a second now to meet these gallants,
You know what honour is,

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Sir you must pardon us,
We go about the same work, you are ready for;
And must fight presently, else we were your servants,

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: God speed you and good day. Exit gent.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Am I thus colted?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Come either yield —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As you are honest gentlemen,
Stay but the next, and then I'll take my fortune,
And if I fight not like a man — fie dinant,
Cold now and treacherous,

sp.speaker: La writ.
sp.l: I understand your causes.
Yours about corn, yours about pins and glasses,
Will you make me mad, have I not all the parcels?
And his petition too, about bell-founding?
Send in your witnesses, what will you have me do?
Will you have me break my heart? my brains are melted;
And tell your master, as I am a gentleman,
His cause shall be the first, commend me to your mistress,
And tell her, if there be an extraordinary feather,
And tall enough for her: I shall dispatch you too,
I know your cause, for transporting of farthingales
Trouble me no more, I say, again to you,
No more vexation: bid my wife send me some puddings;
I have a cause to run through, requires puddings,
Puddings enough. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: God speed you, sir.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Would he would take this fellow.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: A rare youth.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If you be not hasty, sir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Yes, I am hasty,
Exceeding hasty, sir, I am going to the parliament,
You understand this bag, if you have any business
Depending there, be short, and let me hear it,
And pay your fees.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'faith, sir, I have a business,
But it depends upon no parliament.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I have no skill in't then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I must desire you,
'Tis a sword matter, sir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I am no cutler,
I am an advocate, sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How the thing looks?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: When he brings him to fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Be not so hasty,
You wear a good sword.

sp.speaker: La-writ,
sp.l: I know not that,
I never drew it yet, or whether it be a sword —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I must entreat you try, sir, and bear a part
Against these gentlemen, I want a second;
Ye seem a man, and 'tis a noble office.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I am a lawyer, sir, I am no fighter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You that breed quarrels, sir, know best to satisfy.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This is some sport yet.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: If this fellow should fight.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: And for any thing I know, I am an arrant coward,
Do not trust me, I think I am a coward.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Try, try, you are mistaken: walk on gentlemen,
The man shall follow presently.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Are ye mad gentleman?
My business is within this half hour,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's all one,
We'll dispatch within this quarter, there in that bottom,
'Tis most convenient gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Well, we'll wait, sir.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Why this will be a comic fight, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.p: As I am a true man, I cannot fight. Ex. Beaup. Verdone.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Away, away,
I know you can: I like your modesty,
I know you will fight, and so fight, with such mettle,
And with such judgement, meet your enemy's fury;
I see it in your eye, sir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'll be hanged then;
And I charge you, in the King's name, name no more fighting.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I charge you in the King's name play the man,
Which if you do not quickly, I begin with you,
I'll make you dance, do you see your fiddle stick?
Sweet advocate thou shalt fight.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Stand farther gentleman.
Or I'll give you such a dust o'th' chaps —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Spoken bravely,
And like thyself, a noble advocate:
Come to thy tools.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I do not say I'll fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I say thou shalt, and bravely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If I do fight;
I say, if I do, but do not depend upon't,
And yet I have a foolish itch upon me,
What shall become of my writings?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let 'em lie by,
They will not run away, man.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I may be killed too,
And where are all my causes then? my business?
I will not fight, I cannot fight, my causes —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thou shalt fight, if thou hadst a thousand causes,
Thou art a man to fight for any cause,
And carry it with honour.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hum I say you so? if I should
Be such a coxcomb to prove valiant now —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know thou art most valiant.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Do you think so?
I am undone for ever, if it prove so,
I tell you that, my honest friend, for ever;
For I shall never leave quarrelling.
How long must we fight? for I cannot stay,
Nor will not stay, I have business.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll do't in a minute in a moment.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Here will I hang my bag then, it may save my belly,
I never loved cold iron there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You do wisely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Help me to pluck my sword out then, quickly, quickly,
'T has not seen sun these ten years.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How it grumbles?
This sword is vengeance angry.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Now I'll put my hat up,
And say my prayers as I go; away boy,
If I be killed, remember the little lawyer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: They are both come on, that may be a stubborn rascal,
Take you that ground,Enter La-writ.
I'll stay here, fight bravely.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: To't cheerfully my boys, you'll let's have fair play,
None of your foining tricks.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come forward monsieur;Fight.
What hast thou there? A pudding in thy belly?
I shall see what it holds.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Put your spoon home then:
Nay, since I must fight, have at you without wit, sir:
God a mercy bag.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Nothing but bombast in ye?
The rogue winks and fights.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Now your fine fencing, sir:Beau. loses his sword, la. writ treads on it.
Stand off, thou diest on point else,
I have it, I have it: yet further off:
I have his sword.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Then keep it, be sure you keep it.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'll put it in my mouth else.
Stand further off yet, and stand quietly,
And look another way, or I'll be with you.
Is this all? I'll undertake within these two days
To furnish any cutler in this kingdom.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Pox, what a fortune's this? disarmed by a puppy?
A snail? A dog?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: No more o'these words gentleman,
Sweet gentleman no more, do not provoke me,
Go walk i'th' horse fair; whistle gentleman,
What must I do now?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Help me, I am almost breathless.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: With all my heart there's a cold pie for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thou strikest me, fool.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Thou fool, stand further off then,
Deliver, deliver.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Hold fast. He strikes up the others heels, and takes his sword too.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I never fail in't
There's twelve pence, go buy you two leaden daggers,
Have I done well?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Most like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And we two basely lost.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: 'Tis but a fortune,
We shall yet find an hour. Ex. Beau. Verdoone sad.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I shall be glad on't.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Where's my cloak, and my trinkets?
Or will you sight any longer, for a crash or two?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am your noble friend, sir.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What honour shall I do you,
For this great courtesy?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: All I desire of ye,
Is to take the quarrel to yourself, and let me hear no more on't
I have no liking to't, 'tis a foolish matter,
And help me to put up my sword.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Most willingly.
But I am bound to gratify you, and I must not leave you.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I tell you, I will not be gratified,
Nor I will hear no more on't: take the swords too,
And do not anger me but leave me quietly.
For the matter of honour, 'tis at your own disposure,
And so, and so,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a most rare lawyer:
I am sure most valiant. Well dinant as you satisfy me,
I say no more: I am laden like an armourer. Exit. Cler.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To be dispatched upon a sleeveless errand?
To leave my friend engaged, mine honour tainted?
These are trim things. I am set here like a perdue,
To watch a fellow, that has wronged my mistress,
A scurvy fellow, that must pass this way,
But what this scurvy fellow is, or whence,
Or whether his name be William or John,
Or Anthony or Dick or any thing, I know not;
A scurvy rascally fellow. I must aim at,
And there's the office of an ass flung on me.
Sure Cleremont has fought, but how come off,
And what the world shall think of me hereafter:
Well, woman, woman. I must look your rascals,
And lose my reputation: ye have a fine power over us.
These two long hours I have trotted here, and curiously
Surveyed all goers by, yet find no rascal,
Nor any face to quarrel with:La-writ sings within then enters.
What's that?
This is a rascally voice sure it comes this way.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: He struck so hard the basin broke,
And Tarquin heard the sound.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What master thing is this? let me survey it.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: And then he struck his neck in two.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This may be a rascal, but 'tis a mad rascal,
What an alphabet of faces he puts on?
Hey how it fences? if this should be the rogue,
As 'tis the likeliest rogue. I see this day —

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Was ever man for ladies' sake? down, down.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: And what are you good sir? down, down, down, down.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: What's that to you, good sir? down, down.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: A pox on you good, sir, down, down, down,
You with your buckram bag, what make you here?
And from whence come you? I could fight with my shadow now.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Thou fierce man, that like sir Lancelot dost appear,
I need not tell thee what I am, nor eke what I make here.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is a precious knave, stay, stay, good Tristram,
And let me ask thy mightiness a question,
Did ye never abuse a lady?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Not; to abuse a lady, is very hard, sir,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Say you so, sir?
Didst thou never abuse her honour?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Not; to abuse her honour, is impossible.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Certain this is the rascal: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: My name is cock a two, use me respectively,
I will be cock of three else.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What's all this?
You say, you did abuse a lady;

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And that you wronged her honour.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: That's two lies,
Speak suddenly, for I am full of business.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What art thou, or what canst thou be, thou peagoose,
That dar'st give me the lie thus? thou mak'st me wonder.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: And wonder on, till time makes all this plain.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You must not part so, sir, art thou a gentleman?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Ask those, upon whose ruins, I am mounted.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This is some cavaliero knight o'th' sun.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I tell thee, I am as good a gentleman as the Duke;
I have achieved — go follow thy business.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for this lady, sir —

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Why, hang this lady, sir,
And the lady mother too, sir, what have I to do with ladies?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis the little lawyer's voice: has he got my way?
It should be hereabouts .

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Ye dry biscuit rogue,
I will so swinge you for this blasphemy —
Have I found you out?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That should be Dinant's tongue too.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: And I defy thee, do thy worst: o ho quoth Lancelot though.
And that thou shalt know, I am a true gentleman,
And speak according to the phrase triumphant;
Thy lady, is a scurvy lady, and a shitten lady,
And though I never heard of her, a debauched lady,
And thou, a squire of low degree; will that content thee?
Dost thou waylay me with ladies? A pretty sword, sir,
A very pretty sword, I have a great mind to't.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You shall not lose your longing, rogue.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Hold, hold,
Hold dinant, as thou art a gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: As much as you will, my hand is in now.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am your friend, sir: dinant you draw your sword
Upon the gentleman, preserved your honour:
This was my second and did back me nobly,
For shame forbear.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I ask your mercy, sir, and am your servant now.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: May we not fight then?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am sure you shall not now.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I am sorry for't I am sure I'll stay no longer then.
Not a jot longer: are there any more on ye afore?
I will sing still, sir. Exit La-writ,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I look now you should chide me, and 'tis sir,
And with much bitterness, express your anger,
I have deserved : yet when you know —.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I thank ye,
Do you think, that the wrong you have offered me,
The most unmanly wrong, unfriendly wrong —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I do confess —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That boyish sleight —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not so, sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That poor, and base renouncing of your honour,
Can be allayed with words?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I give you way still.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Coloured with smooth excuses? Was it a friend's part,
A gentleman's, a man's that wears a sword,
And stands upon the point of reputation,
To hide his head, then, when his honour called him?
Called him aloud, and lead him to his fortune?
To halt and slip the collar? by my life,
I would have given my life, I had never known thee,
Thou hast eaten canker-like into my judgement
With this disgrace, my whole life, cannot heal again.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This I can suffer too, I find it honest.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Can you pretend an excuse now may absolve you,
Or any thing like honest, to bring you off?
Engage me like an ass?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Expose me like a jade, to tug, and hale through,
Laughed at, and almost hooted? your disgraces,
Invite men's swords, and angers to dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: If you will be patient.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And be abused still: but that I have called thee friend,
And to that name, allow a sanctuary,
You should hear further from me, I would not talk thus:
But henceforth stand upon your own bottom, sir,
And bear your own abuses, I scorn my sword
Should travel in so poor and empty quarrels.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Ha, you done yet? take your whole swinge of anger,
I'll bear all with content.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why were you absent?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You know I am no coward, you have seen that,
And therefore, out of fear, forsook you not:
You know I am not false, of a treacherous nature,
Apt to betray my friend I have fought for you too;
You know no business, that concerned my state,
My kindred, or my life.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where was the fault then?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The honour of that lady I adore
Her credit, and her name: ye know she sent for me,
And with what haste.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What was he that traduced?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The man i'th' moon, I think, hither I was sent,
But to what end —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a pretty flim-flam.

sp.speaker: O. La.
sp.l: I am glad I have met you sir, I have been seeking,
And seeking everywhere .

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And now you have found him,
Declare that business, our ambassador.

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: What's that to ye good man flouter? O sir, my lady.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Prithee no more of thy lady, I have too much on't.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let me have a little, speak to me.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: To you sir?
'Tis more than time: all occasions set aside sir,
Or whatsoever may be thought a business —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: Repair to me within this hour.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: What's that to you? come you, sir, when you're sent for.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: God a mercy Mumpsimus,
You may go dinant, and follow this old fairy,
Till you have lost yourself, your friends, your credit,
And honey out your youth, in rare adventures,
I can but grieve, I have known you.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: Will ye go sir?
I come not often to you with these blessings,
You may believe that thing there, and repent it,
That dogged thing,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Peace touchwood.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will not go:
Go bid your lady seek some fool, to fawn on her
Some unexperienced puppy, to make sport with,
I have been her mirth too long, thus I shake from me
The fetters she put on; thus her enchantments
I blow away like wind, no more her beauty.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: Take heed sir, what you say.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Go forward, dinant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The charms shot from her eyes —

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: Be wise.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Be valiant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: That tongue that tells fair tales to men's destructions
Shall never rack me more.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: Stay there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I will now hear her, see her as a woman,
Survey her and the power man has allowed, sir,
As I would do the course of common things,
Unmoved, unstruck.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Hold there, and I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: She is not fair, and that that makes her proud,
Is not her own, our eyes bestow it on her,
To touch and kiss her, is no blessedness,
A sunburnt Ethiopes lip's as soft as hers.
Go bid her stick some other triumph up,
And take into her favour some dull fool,
That has no precious time to lose, no friends,
No honour, nor no life, like a bold merchant,
A bold and bankrupt man, I have ventured all these,
And split my bottom: return this answer to her,
I am awake again, and see her mischiefs,
And am not now, on every idle errand,
And now coined anger, to be hurried,
And then despised again, I have forgotten her.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If this be true —

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: I am sorry, I have troubled you,
More sorry, that my lady has adventured
So great a favour, in so weak a mind:
This hour you have refused, that when you come to know it,
Will run you mad, and make you curse that fellow,
She is not fair, nor handsome, so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Stay lady, stay, but is there such a business?

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: You would break your neck 'twere yours.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: My back, you would say.

sp.speaker: O. La.
sp.l: But play the friends part still, sir, and undo him,
'Tis a fair office.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I have spoke too liberally.

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: I shall deliver what you say.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You shall be hanged first,
You would fain be prating now; take the man with you.

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: Not I, I have no power.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You may go dinant.

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: 'Tis in's own will, I had no further charge, sir,
Then to tell him what I did, which if I had thought
It should have been received so —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'faith you may,
You do not know, how far it may concern you.
If I perceived any trick in't.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Twill end there.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis my fault then, there is an hour in fortune,
That must be still observed: you think I'll chide you,
When things must be, nay see, an he will hold his head up?
Would such a lady send with such a charge too?
Say she has played the fool, play the fool with her again,
The great fool, the greater still the better,
He shall go with you woman.

sp.speaker: Old lady.
sp.l: As it please him,
I know the way alone else.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Where is your lady?

sp.speaker: O. lady.
sp.l: I shall direct you quickly.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Well, I'll go,
But what her wrongs, will give me leave to say.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll leave that to yourselves: I shall hear from you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: As soon as I come off —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come on then bravely;
Farewell till then, and play the man.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You are merry;
All I expect is scorn: I'll lead you lady.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Champernell, Lamira, Beaupre, Verdoone, Chailote.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We'll venture on him.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Out of my doors I charge thee, see me no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your nephew?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I disclaim him.
He has no part in me, nor in my blood,
My brother that kept fortune bound, and left
Conquest hereditary to his issue
Could not beget a coward.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: I fought, sir,
Like a good fellow, and a soldier too,
But men are men, and cannot make their fates:
Ascribe you to my father, what you please,
I am born to suffer.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: All disgrace: wretch.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good sir be patient.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Was there no tree,
(For to fall by a noble enemy's sword,
A coward is unworthy) nor no river,
To force thy life out backward, or to drown it,
But that thou must survive thy infamy?
And kill me, with the sight of one I hate?
And gladly would forget?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Sir, his misfortune
Deserves not this reproof.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: In your opinion,
'Tis fit you two should be of one belief,
You are indeed, fine gallants, and fight bravely
I'th' city with your tongues, but in the field
Have neither spirit to dare, nor power to do,
Your swords, are all led there.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I know no duty,
( however you may wreak your spleen on him)
That binds me to endure this.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: From dinant
You'll suffer more; that ever cursed I,
Should give my honour up, to the defence
Of such a thing as he is, or my lady
That is all innocent, for whom a dove would
Assume the courage of a daring eagle,
Repose her confidence in one that can
No better guard her. In contempt of you
I love dinant, mine enemy, nay admire him,
His valour claims it from me, and with justice,
He that could fight thus, in a cause not honest,
His sword edged with defence, of right and honour,
Would pierce as deep as lightning, with that speed too,
And kill as deadly.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You are as far from justice,
In him you praise, as equity in the censure,
You load me with.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Dinant? he durst not meet us.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? durst not brother?

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Dared not, I repeat it;

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: Nor was it Cleremont's valour that disarmed us,
I had the better of him; for dinant,
If that might make my peace with you, I dare
Write him a coward, upon every post,
And with the hazard of my life defend it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: If 'twere laid at the stake, you'd lose it, nephew.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Came he not, say you?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: No, but in his room,
There was a devil, hired from some magician
I'th' shape of an attorney.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Twas he did it.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: And his the honour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I could wish dinant —
But what talk I of one that stepped aside,
And durst not come?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am such a friend to truth,
I cannot hear this: why do you detract
Thus poorly (I should say to others basely)
From one, of such approved worth?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Ha! how's this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: From one so excellent, in all that's noble,
Whose only weakness, is excess of courage?
That knows no enemies, that he cannot master,
But his affections, and in them, the worst
His love to me.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: To you?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes, sir to me,
I dare (For what is that, which innocence dares not)
To you profess it, and he shunned the combat
For fear, or doubt of these: blush and repent,
That you in thought, ere did that wrong to valour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Why, this is rare.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Before heaven, exceeding rare;
Why modest lady, you that sing such encomiums
Of your first suitor —

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: How can ye convince us
In our reports?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With what you cannot answer,
'Twas my command that stayed him.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Your command?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Mine, sir, and had my will ranked with my power,
And his obedience, I could have sent him
With more ease, weaponless to you, and bound,
Then have kept him back, so well he loves his honour
Beyond his life.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Better, and better still,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I wrought with him in private to divert him
From your assured destruction, had he met you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: In private?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes, and used all arts, all charms,
Of one that knew herself the absolute mistress
Of all his faculties.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Gave all rewards too
His service could deserve; did not he take
The measure of my sheets?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Do not look yellow,
I have cause to speak; frowns cannot fright me,
By all my hopes, as I am spotless to you,
If I rest once assured, you do but doubt me,
Or curb me of that freedom, you once gave me —

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I'll not alone, abuse your bed, that's nothing,
But to your more vexation, 'tis resolved on,
I'll run away, and then try if dinant
Have courage to defend me.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Impudent!

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: And on the sudden —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How are ye transformed,
From what you were?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I was an innocent virgin,
And I can truly swear, a wife as pure
As ever lay by husband, and will die so,
Let me live unsuspected, I am no servant,
Nor will be used like one: if you desire
To keep me constant, as I would be, let
Trust and belief in you, beget, and nurse it;
Unnecessary jealousies, make more whores
Than all baits else, laid to entrap our frailties.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: There's no contesting with her, from a child
Once moved, she hardly was to be appeased,
Yet I dare swear her honest.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: So I think too,
On better judgement: I am no Italian
To lock her up; nor would I be a Dutchman,
To have my wife, my sovereign, to command me:
I'll try the gentler way, but if that fail,
Believe it, sir, there's nothing but extremes,
Which she must feel from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That, as you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: You have won the breeches, madam, look up sweetly,
My lord limps towards you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You will learn more manners.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: This is a fee, for counsel that's unasked for.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Come, I mistook thee sweet, prithee forgive me,
I never will be jealous: ere I cherish
Such a mechanic humour; I'll be nothing;
I'll say dinant, is all that thou wouldst have him,
Will that suffice?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Use thy freedom
Unchecked, and unobserved, if thou wilt have it,
These shall forget their honour, I my wrongs
We'll all dote on him, hell be my reward
If I dissemble.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And that hell take me
If I affect him, he's a lustful villain,
(But yet no coward) and solicits me
To my dishonour, that's indeed a quarrel,
And truly mine, which I will so revenge,
As it shall fright, such as dare only think
To be adulterers.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Use thine own ways,
I give up all to thee.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O women, women!
When you are pleased you are the least of evils.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: I'll rhyme to't, but provoked, the worst of devils.

div.stage: Enter monsier Sampson, and three clients.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: I know monsieur lawrit.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Would he knew himself, sir.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: He was a pretty lawyer, a kind of pretty lawyer.
Of a kind, of unable thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: A fine lawyer, sir,
And would have firked you up a business,
And out of this court into that.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Ye are too forward,
Not so fine my friends, something he could have done,
But short, short.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: I know your worship's favour,
You are nephew to the judge, sir.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: It may be so,
And something may be done, without trotting i'th' dirt, friends;
It may be I can take him in his chamber,
And have an hour's talk, it may be so,
And tell him that in's ear, there are such courtesies:
I will not say, I can.

sp.speaker: 3 Cly.
sp.l: We know you can, sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Peradventure I, peradventure no: but where's lawrit?
Where's your sufficient lawyer?

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: He's blown up, sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Run mad, and quarrels, with the dog he meets;
He is no lawyer, of this world now.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Your reason?
Is he defunct? is he dead?

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: No, he's not dead yet, sir;
But I would be loath to take a lease on's life for two hours:
Alas, he is possessed sir, with the spirit of fighting,
And quarrels with all people; but how he came to it —

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: If he fight well, and like a gentleman,
The man may fight, for 'tis a lawful calling.
Look you my friends, I am a civil gentleman,
And my lord my uncle loves me.

sp.speaker: 3 Cly.
sp.l: We all know it, sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I think he does, sir, I have business too, much business,
Turn you some forty or fifty causes in a week;
Yet when I get an hour of vacancy,
I can fight too my friends, a little does well,
I would be loath to learn to fight.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: But and't please you, sir,
His fighting has neglected all our business,
We are undone, our causes cast away, sir,
His not appearance.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There he fought too long
A little, and fight well, he fought too long indeed friends;
But ne'er the less, things must be, as they may,
And there be ways —

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: We know, sir, if you please —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Something I'll do; go rally up your causes.

div.stage: Enter La-writ, and a gentleman at the door.

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Now you may behold sir,
And be a witness, whether we lie or no.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'll meet you at the ordinary, sweet gentlemen,
And if there be a wench or two —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We'll have 'em.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: No handling any duels before I come,
We'll have no going less, I hate a coward.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There shall be nothing done.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Make all the quarrels
You can devise before I come, and let's all fight,
There is no sport else.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We'll see what may be done, sir,

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Ha? Monsieur lawrit?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Baffled in way of business,
My causes cast away, judgement against us?
Why there it goes

sp.speaker: 2 client
sp.l: What shall we do the whilst sir?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Breed new dissensions, go hang yourselves
'Tis allo ne to me; I have a new trade of living.

sp.speaker: 1 client
sp.l: Do you hear what he says sir?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The gentleman, speaks finely

sp.speaker: La Wr.
sp.l: Will any of you fight? Fightings my occupation
If you find yourselves aggrieved;

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: A complete gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Avaunt thou buckram budget of petitions,
Thou spittle of lame causes; I lament for thee,
And till revenge be taken —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis most excellent.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: There every man choose his paper, and his place.
I'll answer ye all, I will neglect no man's business
But he shall have satisfaction like a gentleman,
The judge may do and not do, he's but a monsieur

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You have nothing of mine in your bag, sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I know not sir,
But you may put any thing in, any fighting thing

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It is sufficient, you may hear hereafter.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I rest your servant sir,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No more words gentlemen
But follow me, no more words as you love me,
The gentlemans, a noble gentleman.
I shall do what I can, and then —

sp.speaker: Client
sp.l: We thank you sir,Exit Sam. and clients.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Not a word to disturb him, he's a gentleman.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: No cause go? Oh my side the judge cast all?
And because I was honourably employed in action,
And not appeared, pronounce? 'tis very well,
'Tis well faith, 'tis well, judge.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Who have we here?
My little furious lawyer?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I say 'tis well,
But mark the end.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How he is metamorphized?
Nothing of lawyer left not a bit of buckram,
No soliciting face now,
This is no simple conversion
Your servant sir, and friend.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You come in time, sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The happier man, to be at your command then.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You may wonder to see me thus; but that's all one
Time shall declare; 'tis true I was a lawyer,
But I have mend that coat, I hate a lawyer,
I talked much in the court, now I hate talking
I did you the office of a man.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I must confess it,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: And budged not, no I budged not

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No, ye did not,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: There's it then, one good turn requires another

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Most willing sir, I am ready at your service

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: There read, and understand, and then deliver it

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is a challenge sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: 'Tis very like sir,
I seldom now write sonnets

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: O admirantis,
To monsieur Vertaigne the precedent,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I choose no fool sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why he's no sword man sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Let him learn, let him learn,
Time that trains chickens up, will teach him quickly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why he's a judge, an old man.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Never too old.
To be a gentleman; and he that is a judge
Can judge best what belongs to wounded honour;
There are my griefs he has cast away my causes,
In which he has bowed my reputation.
And therefore judge, or no judge,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pray be ruled sir,
This is the maddest thing —

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You will not carry it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I do not tell you so, but if you may be persuaded

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: You know how you used me, when I would not fight,
Do you remember gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The devils in him.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I see it in your eyes, that you dare it
You have a carrying face, and you shall carry it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: The least is banishment

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Be banished then;
'Tis a friend's part, we'll meet in Africa,
Or any corner of the earth.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Say he will not fight,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I know then what to say take you no care sir,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Well, I will carry it, and deliver it,
And tomorrow morning meet you in the lover,
Till when, my service,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: A judge, or no judge, no judge. Exit La-wr.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is the prettiest rogue that 'Ere I read of,
None to provoke to th' field, but the old precedent;
What face shall I put on? if I come in earnest,
I am sure to wear a pair of bracelets;
This may make some sport yet, I will deliver it
Here comes the precedent.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I shall find time gentlemen,
To do your causes good, is not that Cleremont.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: 'Tis he my lord?

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Why does he smile upon me?
Am I become ridiculous? has your fortune sir
Upon my son made you contemn his father?
The glory of a gentleman, is fair bearing,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Mistake me not my lord, you shall not find that;
I come with no blown spirit to abuse you,
I know your place, and honour due unto it,
The reverence to your silver age and virtue,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Your face is merry still.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: So is my business,
And I beseech your honour, mistake me not
I have brought you from a wild, or rather mad man
As mad a piece — of you were wont to love mirth,
In your young days, I have known your honour woe it
This may be made no little one, 'tis a challenge sir,
Nay start not I beseech you, it means you no harm
Nor any man of honour, or understanding
'Tis to steal from your serious hours a little laughters
I am bold to bring it to your lordship,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: 'Tis to me indeed.
Do they take me for a sword man, at these years?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis only worth your honour's mirth that's all sir,
T'had been in me else a saucy rudeness.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: From one lawrit, a very punctual challenge,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: But if your lordship mark it, no great matter

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I have known such a wrangling advocate,
Such a little figent thing; o I remember him,
A notable talking knave, now out upon him,
Has challenged me down right, defied me mortally
I do remember too, I cast his causes

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why there's the quarrel sir, the mortal quarrel

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Why what a knave is this? as you're? Gentleman
Is there no further purpose but mere mirth?
What a bold man of war, he invites me roundly

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If there should be, I were no gentleman.
Nor worthy of the honour of my kindred,
And though I am sure your lordship hate my person,
Which time may bring again into your favour,
Yet for my manners —

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: I am satisfied,
You see sir, I have out lived those days of fighting,
And therefore cannot do him the honour to beat him myself
But I have a kinsman, much of his ability
His wit and carriage, for this calls him fool,
One that will spit as senseless fire, as this fellow

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And such a man to undertake, my lord,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Nay he's too forward, these two pitch barrels together

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Upon my soul no harm.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: It makes me smile,
Why what a stinking smother will they utter?
Yes he shall undertake sir, as my champion,
Since you propound it mirth, I'll venture on it
And shall defend my cause, but as you're honest
Sport not with blood.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Think not so basely, good sir,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: A squire shall wait upon you from my kinsman,
Tomorrow morning, make your sport at full,
You want no subject, but no wounds.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's my care

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.p: And so good day. Exit Vertaine and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Many unto your honour,
This is a noble fellow of a sweet spirit,
Now must I think how to contrive this matter,
For together they shall go. Enter Dinant.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O Cleremont
I am glad I have found thee,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I can tell thee rare things,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: O I can tell thee rarer,
Dost thou love me?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Love thee?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Dost thou love me dear
Darest thou for my sake?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Any thing that's honest

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Though it be dangerous

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pox oh dangerous

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Nay wondrous dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Wilt thou break my heart?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Along with me then.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I must part tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You shall, you shall, be faithful for this night
And thou hast made thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O nurse welcome, where's dinant?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: He is at my back
'Tis the most liberal gentleman, this gold,
He gave me for my pains, nor can I blame you,
If you yield up the for't

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? yield it up?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I know not, he that loves, and gives so largely,
And a young lord to boot, or I am cozened
May enter everywhere ,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou'lt make me angry.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Why if you are I hope here's on will please you,
Look on him with my eyes, good luck go with you
Were I young for your sake. —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I thank thee nurse,

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I would be tractable, and as I am —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Leave the room,
So old, and so immodest? and be careful,
Since whispers will make sleeping jealousies.
That none disturb my lord. Exit nurse.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will you dispatch?
Till you come to the matter be not rapt thus,
Walk in, walk in, I am your scout for once,
You owe me the like service,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And will pay it,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As you respect our lives, speak not so loud

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why, to it in dumb show then, I am silenced

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be not so hasty sir, the golden apples,
Had a fell dragon for their guard, your pleasures
Are to be attempted with Herculean danger,
Or never to be gotten

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Speak the means,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thus briefly my lord sleeps now, and alas,
Each night he only sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Go keep her stirring,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now if he wake, as sometimes he does,
He only stretches out his hand and feels,
Whether I am a-bed , which being assured of
He sleeps again; but should he miss me, valour
Could not defend our lives,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Servant's have servile faiths, nor have I any
That I dare trust; on noble Cleremont
We safely may rely

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What man can do,
Command and boldly,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thus then in my place,
You must lie with my lord,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: With an old man?
Two beards together? that's preposterous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: There is no other way, and though 'tis dangerous
He having servants within call; and armed too,
Slaves feed to act, all that his jealousy,
And rage commands them, yet a true friend should not
Check at the hazard of a life,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I thank you,
I love my friend, but know no reason why
To hate myself, to be a kind of pander,
You see I am willing,
But to betray mine own throat you must pardon,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Then I am lost, and all my hopes defeated
Were I to hazard ten times more for you,
You should find, Cleremont —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You shall not out do me,
Fall what may fall, I'll do't

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But for his beard —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To cover that you shall have my night linen,
And you disposed of, my dinant and I,
Will have some private conference.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Private doing,
Or I'll not venture,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That's as we agree. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter nurse and charloth, pass o'er the stage with pillows night clothes and such things.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What can this woman do, preserving her honour?
I have given her all the liberty that may be
I will not be far off though; nor I will not be jealous
Nor trust too much, I think she is virtuous,
Yet when I hold her best, she's but a woman,
As full of frailty as of faith, a poor sleight woman,
And her best thoughts, but weak fortifications,
There may be a mean wrought. Well, let 'em work then,
I shall meet with it: till the signs be monstrous,
And stick upon my head, I will not believe it,Stands private.
She may be and she may not: now to my observation.

sp.speaker: Din:
sp.l: Why do you make me stay so? if you love me —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You are too hot, and violent.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why do you shift thus
From one chamber to another?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A little delay, sir,
Like fire, a little sprinkled o'er with water,
Makes the desires burn clear, and ten times hotter.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why do you speak so loud? I pray go in
Sweet mistress I am mad, time steals away,
And when we would enjoy —.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now fie, fie servant,Wine.
Like sensual beasts, shall we enjoy our pleasures?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pray do but kiss me then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why, that I will, and you shall find anon, servant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Oftly for heaven's sake, you know my friend's engaged,
A little now, now; will you go in again?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why do you laugh so loud? precious,
Will you betray me? ha my friend's throat cut?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Come, come, I'll kiss thee again.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Will you so? you are liberal,
If you do cozen me —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Wine, wine, a draught or two.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What does this woman here?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She shall not hinder you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: This might have been spared,
'Tis but delay, and time lost: pray send her softly off.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sit down, and mix your spirits with wine,
I will make you another Hercules.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I dare not drink;
Fie, what delays you make? I dare not,Recorders.
I shall be drunk presently and do strange things then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Not drink a cup with your mistress? O the pleasure.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lady, why this? Music.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We must have mirth to our wine, man.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl — o'th' music.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: God-a-mercy wench,
If thou dost cuckold me, I shall forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: The house will all rise now, this will disturb all.
Did you do this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
