sp.l: Peace, and sit quiet, fool,
You love me, come, sit down and drink.

sp.speaker: Cler,
sp.l: What a devil ail you?
How cold I sweat? A hog's pox, stop your pipes,Music.
The thing will wake: now, now methinks I find
His sword just gliding through my throat: what's that?
A vengeance choke your pipes. Are you there lady?
Stop, stop those rascals; do you bring me hither
To be cut into minced meat? Why dinant?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I cannot do withal;
I have spoke, and spoken: I am betrayed, and lost too.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Do you hear me? do you understand me?
Plague dam your whistles. Music ends.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twas but an oversight, they have done, lie down.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Would you had done too.
You know not
In what a misery, and fear I lie.
You have a lady in your arms.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I would have —The recorders again.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll watch you, goodman wood have.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Remove for heaven's sake,
And fall to that you come for.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lie you down,
'Tis but an hour's endurance now.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I dare not, softly sweet lady, — heart?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but your fear, he sleeps still soundly,
Lie gently down.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pray make an end.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Come, madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: These chambers are too near. Ex. Din. Lam.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I shall be nearer;
Well, go thy ways. I'll trust thee through the world,
Deal how thou wilt: that that I never feel,
I'll never fear. Yet by the honour of a soldier,
I hold thee truly noble. How these things will look,
And how their bloods will curdle? play on children,
You shall have pap anon. O thou grand fool,
That thou knowest, but thy fortune —Music done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Peace, good madam,
Stop her mouth dinant, it sleeps yet, pray be wary,
Dispatch, I cannot endure this misery,
I can hear nothing more; I'll say my prayers,
And down again —Whistle within.
A thousand larums, fall upon my quarter,
Heaven send me off; when I lie keeping courses.
Pl — of your fumbling dinant; how I shake?
'Tis still again. Would I were in the Indies. Exit Cler.

div.stage: Enter Dinant, and Lamira. A light within.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Why do ye use me thus? thus poorly? basely?
Work me into a hope, and then destroy me?
Why did you send for me? this new way train me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Madman, a fool, and false man, now I'll show thee man

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pray put your light out.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No I'll hold it thus,
That all chaste eyes, may see thy lust, and scorn it,
Tell me but this, when you first doted on me,
And made suit to enjoy me, as your wife,
Did you not hold me honest?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, most virtuous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And did not that appear, the only lustre
That made me worth your love, and admiration?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I must confess —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why would you deal so basely?
So like a thief? A villain?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace, good madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I'll speak aloud too; thus maliciously,
Thus breaking all the rules of honesty,
Of honour, and of truth, for which I loved you,
For which, I called you servant, and admired you,
To steal that jewel, purchased by another
Piously set in wedlock, even that jewel,
Because it had no flame, you held unvaluable:
Can he that has loved good, dote on the devil?
For he that seeks a whore, seeks but his agent:
Or am I of so wild, and low of blood,
So nursed in infamies?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I do not think so,
And I repent.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That will not serve your turn, sir.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It was your treaty drew me on.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But it was your villainy,
Made you pursue it: I drew you but to try
How much a man, and nobly you durst stand,
How well you had deserved the name of virtuous;
But you, like a wild torrent, mixed with all
Beastly and base affections came floating on,
Swelling your poisoned billows —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Will you betray me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To all the miseries, a vexed woman may.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Let me but out,
Give me but room to toss my sword about me,
And I will tell you, you're a treacherous woman,
Oh that I had but words!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They will not serve you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But two-edged words to cut thee; a lady traitor?
Perish by a proud puppet? I did you too much honour,
To tender you my love, too much respected you,
To think you worthy of my worst embraces.
Go, take your groom, and let him dally with you,
Your greasy groom; I scorn to imp your lame stock,
You are not fair, nor handsome, I lied loudly.
This tongue abused you, when it spoke you beauteous.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, 'tis brave.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Put out your light,
Your lascivious eyes, are flames enough
For fools to find you out: a lady plotter?
Must I begin, your sacrifice of mischief?
I and my friend, the first fruits of that blood,
You and your honourable husband aim at?
Crooked and wretched you are both.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To you, sir,
Yet to the eye of justice, straight as truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Is this a woman's love? A woman's mercy?
Do you profess this seriously? do you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Pl — light upon your scorns, upon your flatteries
Upon your tempting faces, all destructions:
A bedrid winter hang upon your cheeks,
And blast, blast, blast, those buds of pride that point you;
Death in your eyes to fright men from these dangers.
Raise up your trophy Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What a vengeance ail you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: What dismal noise, is there, no honour in you?
Cleremont, we are betrayed, betrayed, sold by a woman,
Deal bravely for thyself.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This comes of rutting:
Are we made stales to one another?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, we are undone, lost.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You shall pay for't greybeard:
Up up, you sleep your last else. Lights above, two servants and Anabell.

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: No not yet, sir,
Lady, look up: would you have wronged this beauty?
Wake so tender a virgin, with rough terms?
You wear a sword; we must entreat you leave it.

sp.speaker: 2 serv.
sp.l: Fie sir, so sweet a lady?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Was this my bedfellow? pray give me leave to look,
I am not mad yet, I may be, by and by.
Did this lie by me?
Did I fear this? is this a cause to shake at?
Away with me for shame, I am a rascal.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Laimra, Anabel, Cleremont, and two servants.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I am amazed too.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We'll recover you.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: You walk like robin-good-fellow, all the house over
And every man afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well lady.
The honour of this deed, will be your own,
The world shall know your bounty.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What shall we do with 'em?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Geld me,
For 'tis not fit I should be a man again,
I am an ass, a dog.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Take your revenges,
You know my husband's wrongs, and your own losses.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: A brave man, an admirable brave man;
Well, well, I would not be so tried again;
A very handsome proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will you let me lie by her, but one hour more,
And then hang me?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: We wait your malice, put your swords home bravely,
You have reason to seek blood.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Not as you are noble.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hands off and give them liberty, only disarm 'em.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: We have done that already.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: You are welcome gentlemen,
I am glad my house, has any pleasure for you,
I keep a couple of ladies here, they say fair,
And you are young, and handsome gentlemen;
Have you any more mind to wenches?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To be abused too? Lady, you might have helped this,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir now 'tis past, but 't may be I may stand,
Your friend hereafter, in a greater matter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Never whilst you live.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot tell — now sir a parting hand.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Down and roses:
Well, I may live to see you again. A dull rogue,
No revelation in thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Were you well frighted?
Were your fits, from the heart, of all colds and colours?
That's all your punishment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: It might have been all yours,
Had not a blockhead undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Your swords you must leave to these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: And now, when you dare fight,
We are on even ice again.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis well:
To be a mistress, is to be a monster,
And so I leave your house, and you for ever.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Leave your wild lusts, and than you are a master.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You may depart too.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I had rather stay here.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Faith we shall fright you worse.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not in that manner,
There's five hundred crowns, fright me but so again.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Come Cleremont, this is the hour of fool.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Wiser the next shall be or we'll to school. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: How coolly these hot gallants are departed?
Faith cousin 'twas unconscionably done,
To lie so still and so long.

sp.speaker: Anab.
sp.l: 'Twas your pleasure,
If 'twere a fault I may hereafter mend.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O, my best wife.
Take now what course thou wilt, and lead what life.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The more trust you commit, the more care still,
Goodness and virtue, shall attend my will.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Let's laugh this night out now and count our gains,
We have our honours home, and they their pains.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: It holds, they will go thither.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To their summer house?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thither i'th' evening, and which is the most infliction,
Only to insult upon our miseries.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are you provided?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Thoroughly?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Basta enough, I have your mind, I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: At such an hour.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Have I a memory?
A cause, and will to do? thou art so sullen —

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And shall be, till I have a fair reparation.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have more reason, for I scaped a fortune,
Which if I come so near again: I say nothing,
But if I sweat not in another fashion —
Oh, a delicate wench.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: 'Tis certain a most handsome one.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And methought the thing was angry with itself too
It lay so long concealed but I must part with you,
I have a scene of mirth, to drive this from my heart,
And my hour is come.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Miss not your time.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I dare not. Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I presume, sir, you now need no instruction,
But fairly know, what belongs to a gentleman;
You bear your uncle's cause.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Do not disturb me,
I understand my cause, and the right carriage.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Be not too bloody.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: As I find my enemy; if his sword bite,
If it bite, sir, you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No doubt he is valiant,
He durst not undertake else,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: He's most welcome,
As he is most valiant, he were no man for me else.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But say he should relent.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: He dies relenting,
I cannot help it, he must die relenting,
If he pray, praying ipso facto, praying,
Your honourable way, admits no prayer,
And if he sight, he falls, there's his quiet us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You're nobly punctual, let's retire and meet 'em,
But still, I say, have mercy.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: I say, honour. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Champernell, Lamira, Anabell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Charlote and a servant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Will not you go sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Go? I'll fly with thee,
I stay behind?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My father will be there too,
And all our best friends,

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And if we be not merry,
We have hard luck, lady.

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Faith let's have a kind of play.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What shall it be?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: The story of dinant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With the merry conceits of Cleremont,
His fits and fevers.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: But I'll lie still no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That, as you make the play, 'twill be rare sport,
And how 'twill vex my gallants, when they hear it?
Have you given order for the coach?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: My easy nag, and pad.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis making ready.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Where are your horses?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ready at an hour, sir: we'll not be last.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Fie, what a night shall we have?
A roaring, merry night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll fly at all, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll fly at thee too, finely, and so ruffle thee,
I'll try your art, upon a country pallet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brag not too much, for fear I should expect it,
Then if you fail —

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Thou sayest too true, we all talk,
But let's in, and prepare, and after dinner
Begin our mirthful pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He that's sad,
A crab-faced mistress cleave to him for this year. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Since it cannot be the judge —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis a great deal better.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: You are sure, he is his kinsman? A gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As arrant a gentleman, and a brave fellow,
And so near to his blood —

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: It shall suffice,
I'll set him further off, I'll give a remove
Shall quit his kindred, I'll lop him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Will ye kill him?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: And there were no more cousins in the world I kill him,
I do mean, sir, to kill all my lords kindred.
For every cause a cousin.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How if he have no more cousins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: The next a kin then, to his lordship's favour,
The man he smiles upon.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why this is vengeance, horrid, and dire.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I love a dire revenge:
Give me the man, that will all others kill,
And last himself,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You stole that resolution.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I had it in a play, but that's all one,
I wooed see it done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Come, you must be more merciful.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: To no lords cousins in the world, I hate 'em;
A lords cousin to me is a kind of cockatrice,
If I see him first, he dies.
A strange antipathy,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: What think you of their nieces?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If I like 'em,
They may live, and multiply; 'tis a cold morning.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis sharp indeed; you have broke your fast.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: No verily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Your valour would have asked a good foundation.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang him, I'll kill him fasting.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Here they come,
Bear yourself in your language, smooth and gently,
When your swords argue.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Pray sir spare your precepts.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I have brought you sir —

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, no words,
You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I thank you, sir, few words.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I'll kill you for your uncle's sake.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I love you,
I'll cut your throat, for your own sake.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I esteem of you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Let's render 'em honest, and fair, gentlemen,
Search my friend, I'll search yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's quickly done.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You come with no spells, nor witchcrafts?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I come fairly, to kill him honestly.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang spells, and witchcrafts,
I come to kill my lords nephew like a gentleman,
And so I kiss his hand.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This doublet is too stiff.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Off wilt, I hate it,
And all such fortifications, feel my skin,
If that be stiff, flay that off too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis no soft one.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Off, wilt, I say:
I'll fight with him, like a flead cat.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are well, you are well. Put off.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: You must uncase too.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, sir.
But tell me this, why should I mix mine honour
With a fellow, that has ne'er a lace in's shirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's a main point, my friend has two.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's true, sir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Base and degenerate cousin, dost not thou know
An old, and tattered colours, to the enemy,
Is of more honour, and shows more ominous?
This shirt, five times, victorious I have fought under,
And cut through squadrons, of your curious cut-works,
As I will do through thine, shake, and be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This is unanswerable.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But may I fight, with a foul shirt?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Most certain, so it be a fighting shirt,
Let it be ne'er so foul, or lousy, Caesar wore such a one.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Saint Denis then: I accept your shirt.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not so forward, first you must talk,
'Tis a main point, of the French method,
Talk civilly, and make your cause authentic.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No weapon must be near you, nor no anger.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you have done, then stir your resolutions,
Take to your weapons bravely.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: 'Tis too cold;
This for a summer fight.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not for a world, you should transgress the rules.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis peevish weather,
I had rather fight without.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: An 'twere in a river.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Where both stood up to th' chins.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Then let's talk quickly,
Pl — of this circumstance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Are the horses come yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes certain: give your swords to us, now civilly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: We'll stand a while off; take the things, and leave 'em,
You know when, and let the children play:
This is a dainty time of year for puppies,
Would the old lord were here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He would die with laughter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am sorry I have no time, to see this game out,
Away, away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here's like to be a hot fight,
Call when you're fit. Ex. Cler. and gent.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Why look you sir, you seem to be a gentleman,
And you come in honour of your uncle, boh, boh, 'tis very cold;
Your uncle has offered me some few affronts,
Passed flesh and blood to bear: boh, boh, wondrous cold.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My lord, mine uncle, is an honourable man,
And what he offers, boh, boh, cold indeed,
Having made choice of me, an unworthy kinsman,
Yet, take me with you: boh, boh, pestilence cold,
Not altogether.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Boh, boh, I say altogether.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You say you know not what then: boh, boh, sir.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Sir me with your sword in your hand;
You have a scurvy uncle, you have a most scurvy cause,
And you are — boh, boh.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Boh, boh, what?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: A shitten scurvy cousin.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: Our swords? our swords?
Thou art a dog, and like a dog: our swords?

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Our weapons gentlemen: ha? where's your second?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Where's yours?

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: So ho? our weapons?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Wa, ha, ho, our weapons?
Our doublets and our weapons, I am dead.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Firsts? second? third? A pl — be wi' you gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Are these the rules of honour? I am starved.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: They are gone, and we are here; what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a couple of faggots.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Hang a couple of faggots;
Darest thou take a killing cold with me?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I have it already.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Rogues, thieves, boh boh, run away with our doublets?
To fight at buffets now, 'twere such a may-game.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: There were no honour in't, p — on't, 'tis scurvy.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Or to revenge my wrongs at fifty-cuffs.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My lord, mine uncle's cause, depend on boxes?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Let's go in quest, if ever we recover 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Ay, come, our colds together, and our doublets.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: Give me thy hand; thou art a valiant gentleman.
I say, if ever we recover 'em —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let's get into a house and warm our hearts.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: There's ne'er a house within this mile, beat me,
Kick me, and beat me as I go, and I'll beat thee too,
To keep us warm; if ever we recover 'em —
Kick hard, I am frozen: so, so, now I feel it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I am dull yet.

sp.speaker: La-w.
sp.l: I'll warm thee I'll warm thee. — gentlemen,
Rogues, thieves, thieves: run, now I'll follow thee. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell Beaupre, Verdoone, Lamira, Annabell. Charlote, nurse.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Use legs, and have legs.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: You that have legs say so,
I put my one to too much stress.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: Your hearse, sir,
Will meet you within half a mile,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I like
The walk so well, I should not miss my coach,
Though it were further. Annabel thou art sad:
What ails my niece?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: She's still devising, sister,
How quietly her late bedfellow lay by her.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Old as I am, he would have startled me,
Nor can you blame her.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Had I taken her place.
I know not, but I fear, I should ha' shrieked,
Though he had never offered —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Out upon thee,
Thou wouldst have taught him.

sp.speaker: Charlote.
sp.l: I think, with your pardon,
That you wish now you had.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am glad. I yield youCornet. Music within.
Such ample scope of mirth.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry,
There's no ill meant: ha? Music, and choice music?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis near us in the grove what courteous bounty
Bestows it on us? my dancing days are done;
Yet I would thank the giver, did I know him.

sp.speaker: Verdo.
sp.l: 'Tis questionless, some one of your own village,
That hearing of your purposed journey thither,
Prepares it for your entertainment, and
The honour of my lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I think rather,
Some of your lordship's clients.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: What say you cousin?
If they should prove your suitors?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: That's most likely.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I say, if you are noble, be't who will;
Go presently and thank 'em: I can jump yet,
Or tread a measure.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Like a miller's mare.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I warrant you well enough to serve the country,
I'll make one, and lead the way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Do you note,
How zealous the old crone is?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And you titter
As eagerly as she: come sweet, we'll follow,
No ill can be intended. Mus. ends.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I ne'er feared yet. Exeunt.
This way, this way, come and hear,
You that hold, these pleasures dear,
Fill your ears, with our sweet sound,
Whilst we melt the frozen ground:
This way come, make haste o fair,
Let your clear eyes gild the air;
Come and bless us with your sight,
This way, this way seek delight.

div.stage: Enter a company of gentlemen, like ruffians.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: They are ours but draw them on a little further
From the footpath into the neighbouring thicket,
And we may do't, as safe, as in a castle.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: They follow still; the precedent, Vertaigne
Comes on apace, and Champernell limps after;
The women, as if they had wings, and walked
Upon the air, fly to us.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: They are welcome,
We'll make 'em sport; make a stand here, all know
How we are to proceed.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: We are instructed. Still music within.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: One strain or two more. Gent. off.
sp.stage: Enter Vertaigne, Champernell, Beaupre Verdoone, Lamira, Anabell, nurse, Charlote.
sp.l: Excellent, they are come,

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: We cannot miss, in such a business, yet
Mine ear ne'er failed me. Music for the dance.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Would we were at it once,
I do not walk, but dance.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: You shall have dancing.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Begin, and when I give the word —

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: No more.
Wear instructed. Dance.

sp.speaker: Beaupre.
sp.l: But win us fairly —Now.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: O sir, we do not come to try your valour,
But to possess you, yet we use you kindly
In that, like English thieves, we kill you not,
But are contented with the spoil.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: O heaven!
How hath mine age deserved this?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Hell confound it,
This comes of walking; had I kept my legs,
My legs in my good house, my armour on,
My staff in my rest, and this good sword too, friend,
How I would break and scatter these.

sp.speaker: All gent.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Do you scorn me rogues?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, gentlemen, kind gentlemen,
Or honest keepers of these woods, but hear me,
Be not so rough; if you are taken with
My beauty, as it hath been worth the seeking,
Some one or two of you, try me in private,
You shall not find me squeamish.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Do not kill me,
And do your worst, I'll suffer.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Peace vile creatures.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Do you know me, or my place that you presume not
To touch my person?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: If you are well, rest so,
Provoke not angry wasps.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: You are wasps indeed,
Never created to yield wax, or honey,
But for your country's torment, yet are, if men,
As you seem such in shape, if true born Frenchmen,
However want compels you to these courses,
Rest satisfied with what you can take from us,
(These ladies' honours, and our liberties safe)
We freely give it.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: You give but our own.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Look on these grey hairs, as you would be old,
Their tears, as you would have yours to find mercy,
When justice shall o'ertake you.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Look on me,,
Look on me rascals, and learn of me too,
That have been in some part of your profession,
Before that most of you ere sucked I know it,
I have rode hard, and late too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Take heed, sir.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Then use me, like a brother of the trade,
For I have been at sea, as you on land are,
Restore my matrimony undefiled,
Wrong not my niece. and for our gold or silver,
If I pursue you, hang me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: 'Tis well offered,
And as I said, sweet gentlemen, with sour faces,
If you are high, and want some sport, or so,
(As living without action here, you may do)
Forbear their tender grissels, they are meat
Will wash away, there is no substance in it,
We that are expert in the game, and tough to,
Will hold you play.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: This hen longs to be trodden.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Lackey my horse.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This way, I heard the cries
Of distressed women.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Stand upon your guard.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Who's here? my witty, scornful lady-plot?
In the hands of ruffians,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And my fine cold virgin,
That was insensible of man, and woman?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Justice too,
Without a sword to guard itself?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And valour with its hands bound?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: And the great soldier dull?
Why this is strange;

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Dinant as thou art noble —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As thou art valiant Cleremont. —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As ever I appeared lovely —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you ever hope,
For what I would give gladly —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Pretty conjurations,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All injuries, a little laid behind you

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Show yourselves men, and help us

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Though your many
And gross abuses of me, should more move me
To triumph in your miseries then relieve you, —
Yet that hereafter, you may know that I
The scorn and despised dinant, knows what does.
Belong to honour, thus —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I will say little,Fight.
Speak thou for me,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely fought,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Brave tempers,
To do thus for their enemies.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are lost yet,

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: You that would rescue others, shall now feel
What they were born to,

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: Hurry them away. Exit. Manent Vertaigne, and Champernell.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: That I could follow them,

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: I only can lament my fortune, and desire of heaven
A little life for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The Provost,
Shall fire the woods, but I will find 'em out,
No cave, no rock, nor hell shall keep them from
My searching vengeance.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Oh cold! O fearful cold! plague of all seconds,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O for a pint of burned wine, or a sip
Of aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The rogues have met with these two
Upon my life and robbed 'em

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: As you are honourable gentlemen,
Impart unto a couple of cold combatants,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My lord, mine uncle as I live,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Pox take him.
How that word, has warmed my mouth?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why how now cousin?
Why, why? and where man, have you been? at a poulter's
That you are cassed thus like a rabbit? I could laugh now,
And I shall laugh, for all I have lost my children,
Laugh monstruously

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Give me leave sir,
Laugh more and more, never leave laughing,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Why 'tis such a thing I smell it sir, I smell it,
Such a ridiculous thing, —

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Do you laugh at me my lord?
I am very cold, but that should not be laughed at,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If he had his doublet. —
And his sword by his side, as a gentleman ought to have

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Peace monsieur Sampson.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Come hither little gentleman,

sp.speaker: La Wr.
sp.l: Base is the slave commanded: come to me

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: This is the little advocate

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: What advocate?

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: The little advocate that sent me a challenge,
I told you that my nephew under took it,
And what was like to prove: now you see the issue.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this the little lawyer?

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: You have a sword sir,
And I have none, you have a doublet too,
That keeps you warm, and makes you merry,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If your lordship knew.
The nature, and the nobleness of the gentleman,
Though he show sleight here, and at what gusts of danger
His manhood has arrived,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Be't then.
Men's faces are foolish,
And often head long, over run their fortunes,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That little lawyer, would so prick his ears up,
And bite your honour by the nose.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.p: So niggle about your grave shins lord Vertaigne too

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No more sweet gentleman, no more of that sir,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I will have more, I must have more.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Nay he is as brave a fellow. —

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Have I caught you? Strike him down.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Do not kill him, do not kill him.
No no, no, I will not

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Do you peep again, down down proud heart

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O valour,
Look up brave friend, I have no means to rescue thee,
My kingdom for a sword,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll sword you presently,
I'll claw your skin-coat too.

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Away good Samson,
You go to grass else instantly,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But do not murder my brave friend

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Not one word,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: If you do sirrah, —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Must I go off dishonoured?
Adversity tries valour, so I leave thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Are you a lawyer sir?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I was, I was sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Nay never look, your lawyer's pate is broken
And your litigious blood, about your ears sirrah,
Why do you fight and snarl?

sp.speaker: La. Wr.
sp.l: I was possessed.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I'll dispossess you.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Et tu Brute.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Beat him no more.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Alas sir I must beat him,
Beat him into his business again, he will be lost else.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Then take your way,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Lie still, and do not struggle,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I am patient,
I never saw my blood before, it jades me,
I have no more heart now then a goose.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Why sirrah, why do you leave your trade, your trade of living,
And send your challenges like thunderbolts,
To men of honoured place?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I understand sir,
I never understood, before your beating,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Does this work on you?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Do you thank me for't?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: As well as a beaten man can,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And do you promise me,
To fall close to your trade again? leave brawling

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: If you will give me leave and life,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: And ask this noble man forgiveness?

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: Heartily.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Rise then, and get you gone, and let me hear of you
As of an advocate new vampt; no more words,
Get you off quickly, and make no murmurs
I shall pursue you else,

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I have done sweet gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: But we forget ourselves, our friends and children

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: We'll raise the country first, then take our fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Shall I entreat for what I may command?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Think on my birth,

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Here I am only noble.
A King, and thou in my dominions fool,
A subject and a slave.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be nor a tyrant;
A ravisher of honour, gentle sir,
And I will think ye such, and on my knees,
As to my sovereign, pay a subject's duty,
With prayers and tears,

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I like this humble carriage.
I will walk by, but kneel you still and weep too,
It shows well, while I meditate on the prey,
Before I seize it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is there no mercy, heaven?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Not kiss you?
I will kiss and kiss again,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Savage villain !
My innocence be my strength, I do defy thee,
Thus scorn and spit at thee; will you come on sir,
You are hot, there is a cooler,

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: A virago?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: No, loathsome goat, more, more I am that goddess,
That here with whips of steel in hell hereafter
Scourge rape and theft,

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: I'll try your deity,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My chastity, and this knife held by a virgin,
Against thy lust thy sword and thee a beast.
Call on for the encounter.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: Now what think you? Throws her and takes. her knife.
Are you a goddess?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: In me their power suffers,
That should protect the innocent,

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I am all fire,
And thou shall quench it, and serve my pleasures,
Come partner in the spoil and the reward,
Let us enjoy our purchase

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O dinant!
O heaven! O husband!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O my Cleremont!

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Two are our slaves they call on, bring 'em forth
As they are chained together let them see
And suffer in the object.

div.stage: Enter Dinant and Cleremont bound. By the rest of the gent.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: While we sit
And without pity hear 'em

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By my life,
I suffer more for thee then for myself,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be a man Cleremont, and look upon 'em,
As such that not alone abused our service,
Fed us with hopes most bitter indigestion,
But when love failed, to draw on further mischief,
The baits they laid for us; were our own honours,
Which thus hath made us slaves too, worse than slaves

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: He dies

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: Pray hold, give him a little respite,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I see you now beyond expression wretched,
The wit you bragged of, fooled, that boasted honour,
As you believed compassed with walls of brass,
To guard it sure, subject to be o'er thrown
With the least blast of lust.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A most sad truth.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: That confidence which was not to be shaken
In a perpetual fever, and those favours,
Which with so strong, and ceremonious duty
Your lover and a gentleman long sought for,
Sought, sued, and kneeled in vain for, must you yield up
To a licentious villain, that will hardly,
Allow you thanks for't

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Something I must say too,
And to you pretty one, though crying one;
To be hanged now, when these worshipful benchers please
Though I know not their faces that condemn me,
A little startles me, but a man is nothing,
A maidenhead is the thing, the thing all aim at;
Do not you wish now, and wish from your heart too,
When scarce sweet with my fears, I long lay by you
Those fears you and your good aunt put upon me,
To make you sport you had given a little hint,
A touch or so, to tell me I was mortal,
And by a mortal woman?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pray you no more

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If I had loosed that virgin zone, observe me,
I would have hired the best of all our poets
To have sung so much, and so well in the honour
Of that night's joy, that Ovid's afternoon,
Nor his Corvina should again be mentioned,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I do repent, and wish I had,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's comfort,
But now. —

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Another that will have it offered,
Compel it to be offered, shall enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A rogue, a ruffian.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: As you love your throat, —

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O Cleremont!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O dinant!

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I can but add your sorrows to my sorrows,
Your fears to my fears,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: To your wishes mine.
This slave may prove unable to perform,
Till I perform the task that I was born for,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Amen, amen.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Drag the slaves hence, for you
A while I'll lock you up here study all ways
You can to please me, or the deed being done,
You are but dead.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: This strong vault shall contain you
There think how many for your maidenhead
Have pined away, and be prepared to lose it
With penitence.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: No humane help can save you.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: Help, help?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: You cry in vain, rocks cannot hear you.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: A horrid noise of music within, enter one and opens the chamber door, in which Lamira and Anabell were shut, they in all fear.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O cousin how I shake, all this long night,
What frights and noises we have heard still they increase
The villains put on shapes to torture us,
And to their devil's form such preparations
As if they were a hatching new dishonours,
And fatal ruin, passed dull man's invention
Go not too far and pray good cousin Anabell
Hark a new noise. A strange music. Sackbut and troup music.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: They are exquisite in mischief.
I will go on this room gives no protection,
More than the next what's that? how sad and hollow,
The sound comes to us. Thieves peeping. Lowder.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Groaning? or singing is it?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: The wind I think, murmuring amongst old rooms

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now it grows louder sure some sad presage
Of our foul loss — peep —, look now they peep,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Pox peep 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O give them gentle language,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Give 'em ratsbane. Peep above.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now they are above

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I would they were i th' centre,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou art so foolish desperate,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Since we must lose.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Call 'em brave fellows, gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Call 'em rogues,
Rogues as they are, rude rogues, uncivil villains

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Look an thou wilt, beware dost thou feel the danger?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Till the danger feel me, this will I talk still,
And worse when that comes too; they cannot eat me
This is a punishment, upon our own prides,
Most justly laid; we must abuse brave gentlemen,
Make 'em tame fools and hobby-horses, laugh and jeer at
Such men too, and so handsome and so noble,
That howsoe'er we seemed to carry it
Wooed 'twere to do again,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I do confess cousin,
It was too harsh, too foolish

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Do you feel it?
Do you find it now? take heed o'th' punishment,
We might have had two gallant gentlemen,
Proper young, oh how it tortures me
Two devils now, two rascals two and twenty

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O think not so

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Nay an we scape so modestly —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: May we be worthy any eyes, or knowledge,
When we are used thus?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Why not? why do you cry!
Are we not women still? what were we made for?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But thus, thus basely —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: 'Tis against our wills,
And if there come a thousand so, —

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Out on thee,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are a fool, what we cannot resist,
Why should we grieve and blush for? there be women,
And they that bear the name of excellent women
Would give their whole estates, to meet this fortune

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Hark, a new noise. New found within.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em go on, I fear not,
If wrangling fighting and scratching cannot preserve me
Why so be it cousin; if I be ordained
To breed a race of rogues. —

div.stage: Enter four over the stage with Beaupre and Verdoone bound and halters about their necks.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: They come

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Be firm,
They are welcome.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What mask of death is this? O my dear brother

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My coz to; why now you're glorious villains

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O shall we lose our honours?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Let 'em go,
When death prepares the way, they are but pageants
Why must these die?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Lament your own misfortunes
We perish happily before your ruins,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Has mischief ne'er a tongue?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Yes foolish woman,
Our captains will is death.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You dare not do it
Tell thy base boisterous captain what I say,
Thy lawless captain that he dares not;
Do you laugh you rogue? you pampered rogue?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Good sir,
Good cousin gently, as you're a gentleman, —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: A gentleman? A slave a dog the devil's harbinger

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sir as you had a mother,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: He a mother?
Shame not the name of mother, a she bear
A bloody old wolf bitch, a woman mother?
Looks that rude lump, as if he had a mother?
Entreat him? hang him, do thy worst thou dar'st not,
Thou dar'st not wrong their lives, thy captain dares not
They are persons of more price

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Whate'er we suffer
Let not your angers wrong you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You cannot suffer.
The men that do this deed must live i'th moon
Free from the gripe of justice.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is it not better?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Is it not better? let 'em go on like rascals
And put false faces on; they dare not do it;
Flatter such scabs of nature,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Woman, woman
The next work is with you,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Unbind those gentlemen,
And put their fatal fortunes, on our necks.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As you have mercy do;

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: As you are monsters.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Fright us no more with shipwreck of our honours
Nor if there be a guilt by us committed
Let it endanger those,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I say they dare not,
There be a thousand gallows, ye rogues,
Tortures, ye bloody rogues wheels,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A way.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay,
Stay and I'll flatter too: good sweet faced gentlemen
You excellent in honesty; oh kinsmen!
O noble kinsmen!

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exit Verta. Beaup. and gent.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay yet
The devil and his lovely dam walk with you,
Come fortify yourself, if they do die,
Which all their ruggedness, cannot rack into me
They cannot find an hour more innocent,
Nor more friends to revenge 'em.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now stand constant,
For now our trials come,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: This beauties mine
Your minute moves not yet,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She sinks if christian,
If any spark of noble heat. —

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Rise lady
And fearless rise, there's no dishonour meant you,
Do you know my tongue?

sp.speaker: Ana,
sp.l: I have heard it,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Mark it better
I am one that loves you, fairly, nobly loves you
Look on my face?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: No more words, softly
Hark, but hark wisely how, understand well,
Suspect not, fear not

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You have brought me comfort

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: If you think me worthy of your husband,
I am no rogue, nor beggar if you dare do thus —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are monsieur Cleremont,

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I am the same
If you dare venture, speak, if not I leave you,
And leave you to the mercy of these villains
That will not woo ye much,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Save my reputation,
And free me from these slaves.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By this kiss I'll do it
And from the least dishonour they dare aim at you
I have a priest too, shall be ready.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You are forward,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is this my constant cousin? how she whispers,
Kisses and hugs the thief.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: You ll offer nothing

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Till all be tied
Not as I am a gentleman

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Can you relieve my aunt too?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not yet mistress.
But fear nothing all shall be well away quickly
It must be done i'th moment or

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am with ye

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'll know now who sleeps by me, keep your standing

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, and thine own shame dwell with thee?
Is this the constancy she showed the bravery
The dear love and the life, she owed her kinsmen?
O brave tongue valiant glorious woman?
Is this the noble anger you arrived at?
Are these the thieves you scorned the rogues you railed at?
The scabs and scums of nature? O fair modesty,
Excellent virtue, whither art thou fled?
What hand of heaven is over us, when strong virgins
Yield to their fears, and to their fears their fortunes?
Never belief come near me more, farewell wench,
A long farewell from all that ever knew thee
My turn is next,
I am resolved it comes
But in a nobler shape, ha?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Bless ye lady

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Indeed sir. I had need of many blessings,
For all the hours I have had since I came here,
Have been so many curses. How got you liberty?
For I presume you come to comfort me

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: To comfort you, and love you, 'tis most true,
My bondage was as yours, as full of bitterness
And every hour my death.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Heaven was your comfort.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Till the last evening, sitting full of sadness
Wailing, sweet mistress, your unhappy fortunes
Mine own I had the least care of round about me,
The captain, and the company stood gaping,
When I began the story of my love,
To you fair saint, and with so full a sorrow,
Followed each point, that even from those rude eyes,
That never knew what pity meant or mercy
There stole down soft relentings, take heed mistress,
And let not such unholy hearts out do you,
The soft plumed god will see again thus taken,
As men transformed with the strange tale I told
They stood amazed then bid me rise and live,
Take liberty and means to see your person,
And wished me prosperous in your love, wish you so,
Be wise and loving lady, show but you so

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O sir, are these fit hours, to talk of love in?
Shall we make fools of our afflictions?
Can any thing sound sweetly in mine ears,
Where all the noise of bloody horror?
My brother, and my cousin, they are dead sir,
Dead, basely dead, is this an age to fool in?
And I myself, I know not what I shall be
Yet I must thank you and if happily
You had asked me yesterday, when these were living,
And my fears less, I might have hearkened to you,

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Peace to your grief, I bind you to your word.

div.stage: Enter Cleremont Anabell, Beaupre, Verdoone, Charlote nurse, the two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How? do you conjure?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not to raise dreadful apparitions, madam,
But such as you would gladly see.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My brother, and nephew living?

sp.speaker: Beap.
sp.l: And both owe their lives,
To the favour of these gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Who deserve
Our service, and for us, your gracious thanks.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Which I give freely, and become a suitor,
To be hereafter more familiar. Kiss.
With such great worth and virtue,

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: Ever think us,
Your servant's madam.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Why if thou wilt needs know
How we are freed, I will discover it,
And with laconic brevity, these gentlemen
This night encountering with those out laws that
Yesterday made us prisoners, and as we were
Attempted by 'em they with greater courage,
(I am sure with better fortune not alone,
Guarded themselves, but forced the bloody thieves,
Being got between them, and this hellish cave,
For safety of their lives, to fly up higher
Into the woods, all left to their possession
This save your brother, and your nephew from
The gibbet, this redeemed me from my chains,
And gave my friend his liberty this preserved
Your honour ready to be lost.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that
I know this for a lie, and that the thieves
And gentlemen, are the same men, by my practice,
Suborned to this he does deliver it
With such a constant brow, that I am doubtful,
I should believe him too.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: If we did well,
We are rewarded.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Thanks but takes away
From what was freely purposed.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Now by this hand,
You have so cunningly discharged your parts,
That while we live, rest confident you shall
Command dinant and Cleremont, nor Beaupre,
Nor Verdoone scents it: for the ladies, they
Were easy to be guled.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: 'Twas but a jest,
And yet the jest, may chance to break our necks
Should it be known.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Cleremont.
Say, what success?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: As thou wouldst wish, 'tis done lad,
The grove will witness with me, that this night,
I lay not like a block: but how speed you?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I yet am in suspense, devise some means
To get these off, and speedily.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I have it,
Come, we are dull, I think that the good fellows,
Our predecessors in this place, were not
So foolish, and improvident husbands, but
'Twill yield us meat, and wine.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Let's ransack it,
'Tis ours now, by the law.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: How say you sweet one,
Have you an appetite?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: To walk again
I'th woods, if you think fit, rather than eat.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: A little respite prithee; nay blush not,
You ask but what's your own, and warrantable
Monsieur, Beaupre, Verdoone,
What think you of the motion?

sp.speaker: Verd.
sp.l: Lead the way. Ex. manent, Din. and Lamira.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We follow willingly.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: When you shall think fit,
We will expect you.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Now be mistress of
Your promise lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Twas to give you hearing.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: But that word hearing, did include a grant,
And you must make it good.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Must?

sp.speaker: D●n.
sp.l: Must, and shall,
I will be fooled no more, you had your tricks;
Made properties, of me, and of my friend;
Presumed upon your power, and whipped me with
The rod of mine own dotage: do not flatter
Yourself, with hope, that any humane help
Can free you, and for aid by miracle;
A base unthankful woman is unworthy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You will not force me?
Rather than injury you
With your consent because I will torment you;
I'll make you feel the effects of abused love,
And glory in your torture.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Brother, nephew,
Help, help, for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Tear your throat, cry louder,
Though every leaf, these trees bear, were an echo,
And summoned in your best friends to redeem you,
It should be fruitless: 'tis not that I love you,
Or value those delights you prize so high,
That I'll enjoy you, a French crown will buy
More sport, and a companion, to whom,
You in your best trim. are an Aethiop.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Forbear me then.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Not so, I'll do't in spite,
And break that stubborn disobedient will,
That hath so long held out, that boasted honour,
I will make equal with a common whores;
The spring of chastity, that fed your pride,
And grew into a river of vain glory,
I will defile with mud, the mud of lust,
And make it loathsome even to goats.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O heaven!
No pity sir?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: You taught me to be cruel,
And dare you think of mercy? I'll tell thee fool,
Those that surprised thee, were my instruments,
I can plot too, good madam, you shall find it:
And in the stead of licking of my fingers,
Kneeling, and whining like a boy new breeched,
To get a toy forsooth, not worth an apple,
Thus make my way, and with authority,
Command what I would have.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am lost for ever:
Good sir, I do confess my fault, my gross fault,
And yield myself up, miserable guilty;
Thus kneeling, I confess, you cannot study
Sufficient punishments, to load me with;
I am in your power, and I confess again,
You cannot be too cruel: if there be,
Besides the loss of my long guarded honour,
Any thing else to make the balance even:
Pray put it in, all hopes, all helps have left me;
I am girt round with sorrow, hell's about me,
And ravishment, the least that I can look for,
Do what you please.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Indeed I will do nothing,
Nor touch, nor hurt you lady, nor had ever
Such a lewd purpose.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Can there be such goodness,
And in a man so injured?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Be confirmed in't.
I seal it thus: I must confess you vexed me,
In fooling me so often, and those fears,
You threw upon me, called for a requital,
Which now I have returned, all unchaste love
Dinant thus throws away; live to mankind,
As you have done to me, and I will honour
Your virtue, and no more think of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: All I possess, comes short of satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: No compliments: the terrors of this night
Imagine, but a fearful dream, and so
With ease forget it: for dinant, that laboured
To blast your honour, is a champion for it,
And will protect and guard it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis as safe then,
As if a complete army undertook it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Do not persuade me gentle monsieur Sampson,
I am a mortal man again, a lawyer,
My mortal part, I have put off.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Sweet monsieur,
Let but our honours teach us.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Monsieur Sampson
My honourable friend, my valiant friend,
Be but so beaten-forward my brave clients,
I am yours, and you are mine again, be but so thrashed,
Receive that castigation with a cudgel.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Which calls upon us for a reparation.

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: I have, it cost me half a crown, I bear it
All over me, I bear it monsieur Sampson;
The oils, and the old woman, that repairs to me,
To 'noint my beaten body.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It concerns you,
You have been swinged.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Let it concern thee too;
Go and be beaten, speak scurvy words, as I did,
Speak to that lion lord, waken his anger,
And have a hundred bastinadoes, do;
Three broken pates, thy teeth knocked out, do Sampson,
Thy valiant arms and legs beaten to poultices,
Do silly Sampson, do.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: You wrong the gentleman,
To put him out of his right mind thus:
You wrong us, and our causes.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Down with him gentlemen,
Turn him, and beat him, if he break our peace,
Then when thou hast been lamed, thy small guts perished,
Then talk to me, before I scorn thy counsel,
Feel what I feel, and let my lord repair thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And can the brave lawrit —

sp.speaker: 2 Cly.
sp.l: Tempt him no further,
Be warned and say no more.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: If thou dost, Sampson,
Thou seest my Myrmidons, I'll let 'em lose,
That in a moment —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I say nothing, sir, but I could wish —

sp.speaker: La-wr.
sp.l: They shall destroy thee wishing;
There's ne'er a man of these, but have lost ten causes,
Dearer than ten men's lives; tempt, and thou diest:
Go home, and smile upon my lord, mine uncle,
Take money of the men thou meanest to cozen,
Drink wine, and eat good meat, and live discreetly,
Talk little, 'tis an antidote against a beating;
Keep thy hand from thy sword, and from thy laundress placket,
And thou wilt live long.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Give ear, and be instructed.

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: I find I am wiser than a justice of peace now,
Give me the wisdom that's beaten into a man
That sticks still by him: art thou a new man?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
Thy learned precepts have enchanted me,

sp.speaker: La-writ.
sp.l: Go my son Sampson, I have now begotten thee,
I'll send thee causes; speak to thy lord, and live.
And lay my share by, go and live in peace,
Put on new suits, and show fit for thy place;
That man neglects his living, is an ass:Exit. Samp.
Farewell; come cheerly boys, about our business,
Now welcome tongue again, hang swords.

sp.speaker: 1 Cly.
sp.l: Sweet advocate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I know not wench, they may call 'em what they will,
Outlaws, or thieves, but I am sure, to me
One was an honest man, he used me well,
What I did, 'tis no matter, he complained not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I must confess, there was one bold with me too,
Some coy thing, would say rude, but 'tis no matter,
I was to pay a waiting woman's ransom,
And I have don't, and I would pay't again,
Were I ta'ne tomorrow

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Alas, there was no hurt,
If't be a sin, for such as live at hard meat,
And keep a long lent, in the woods as they do,
To taste a little flesh,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: God help the courtiers,
That lie at rack and manger

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I shall love
A thief the better for this while I live,
They are men of a charitable vocation,
And give where there is need, and with discretion,
And put a good speed penny in my purse,
That has been empty twenty years,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Peace nurse,
Farewell, and cry not roast meat, methinks Cleremont
And my lady Anabell are in one night,
Familiarly acquainted.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I observe it,
If she have got a penny too.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: No more,
My lord monsieur Vertaigne the Provost too,
Hast and acquaint my lady,Exit nurse and Charl.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wondrous strange,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir, on my credit,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: On mine honour,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I have been provost-marshall twenty years,
And have trussed up a thousand of these rascals,
But so near Paris yet, I never met with,
One of that brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: We to our cost have,
But will you search the wood

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is beset,
They cannot scape us, nothing makes me wonder,
So much as having you within their power
They let you go; it was a courtesy,
That French thieves use not often, I much pity
The gentle ladies, yet I know not how,
I rather hope than fear
sp.stage: Enter Dinant, Cleremont, Verdoone, Beaupre, Lamira, Anabell, Charlote, nurse.
sp.l: Are these the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: We were such

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: Kill me not, excess of joy,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I see thou livest, but hast thou had no foul play

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No on my soul, my usage hath been noble,
Far from all violence,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How were you freed,
But kiss me first, we'll talk of that at leisure,
I am glad I have thee; niece how you keep off,
As you knew me not?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir, I am where
I owe most duty

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed most true sir,
The man that should have been your bed fellow
Your lordship's bedfellow, that could not smell out
A virgin of sixteen, that was your fool,
To make you merry, this poor simple fellow
Has met the maid again, and now she knows,
He is a man,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: How! is she dishonoured?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Not unless marriage be dishonourable,
Heaven is a witness of our happy contract
And the next priest we meet shall warrant it
To all the world: I lay with her in jest,
'Tis turned to earnest now.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Is this true niece

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: Her blushing silence grants it; nay sir storm not
He is my friend, and I can make this good,
His birth and fortunes equal hers, your lordship
Might have sought out a worse we are all friends too,
All differences end thus. Now sir, unless
You would raise new dissensions make perfect
What is so well begun

sp.speaker: Verta.
sp.l: That were not manly,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Let me persuade you,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Well God give you joy,
She shall not come a beggar to you sir,
For you monsieur dinant 'Ere long I'll show you,
Another Neico, to this not much inferior,
As you shall like proceed

sp.speaker: Din.
sp.l: I thank you sir,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Back then to Paris, well that travel ends
That makes of deadly enemies perfect friends.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: To promise much, before a play begin,
And when 'tis done, ask pardon, were a sin
We'll not be guilty of: and to excuse
Before we know a fault were to abuse
The writers and ourselves, for I dare say
We all are fooled if this be not a play
And such a play as shall, (So should plays do)
Imp times dull wings, and make you merry too
'Twas to that purpose writ, so we intend it
And we have our wished ends, if you commend it.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: I am sent forth to inquire what you decree
Of us and our poets, they will be
This night exceeding merry, so will we
If you approve their labours. They profess
You are their patrons, and we say no less,
Resolve us then, for you can only tell
Whether we have done idly or done well.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
